UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 0,33l bottle from Sörspecialista, Budapest. Bottle No. 2011 042564, bottled on 26.10.2011. Brown hazy color with minimal beige head. Its very viscous. Strong sweet odor banana.Typical fruity banana, vanilla aroma. Sweet taste dominated by the alcohol. Full body with extrame creamy texture and lively carbonation Long finish witch is the mixture of alcohol, wheat, banana, sweetness and bitteness. Its a very special beer. I recommand it for those who like strong alcoholic beers.

Gave fra Rune. Fortært i Skibotn 21 Okt 11. Dyp brun. Veldig uklar. Lavt skum. Søt sitrusaroma. Litt krydder. Veldig kompleks smak: Mye frukt - søt & bitter. Mandler & svisker. Langvarig ettersmak. Blir litt tørr i avslutningen. Litt for mye kullsyre. Mye bunnfall. KI=7

Cloudy brown in color.  Fruity apricot/peach nose along with some spice and malt, almost like peach cobbler.  Basic dried fruit and some sweet malt for flavor.  Overall, very flavorful and drinkable... Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing his bottle!

Pours dark hazy brown with fast fading light head. Aroma is bananas, prunes, and other sweet fruits. Flavor is similar but heavier on the dark fruits, with heavy alcohol notes, caramel and spices and a bit of chocolate. Sticky and thick.

Bottled december 2010, so almost one year of age. Pours a beautiful dark amber with a small tanned rim of head. Aroma is just prunes and banana all over the place. Really rich plum and prune, a yeasty component of banana and fruity esters. Also raisins and dark bread, slight caramel, too. Very similar to port wine, due to the focus on dark fruits. Taste is very similar. Very full bodied, huge mouthfeel. Huge sweetness, lots of plums, raisins, also bready notes and caramel. But the taste has quite some alcohol, which makes the palate somewhat rough. It does taste good, but any day, I would prefer regular Aventinus.
Yeasty, banana, wheat, and stronger than expected in the nose.  The look is cloudy, brown, beige tan head.  The taste is alcohol, banana, clove, wheat, and yeast.

Kickoff to thanksgiving break brew.  Pours cola colored with nice fluffy head. Aroma is sweet wheat.  Taste is of banana, cloves, wheat, candy, toffee, earth, and raisins.  Finish is lingering.  Yum I bought just because I thought I needed eisbock rate, which I dont, but happened upon best in style deliciousness.  Yay luck

First of all, great story (above) for this beer. My first beer of this style. Did anyone else notice the suspended tiny little bubble above the head when they first poured it? Nevermind. Very dark brown cloudy body with a thin bubbly head. Aroma is a bit sweet and somewhat woody/vanilla. Good feel on the palate. The taste is very complex; tough to describe but slightly bitter but pleasant.

Dark brown with a small unstable head.  smell of berries, banana and a little alcohol. tastes sweet with lots of berries, a bit of banana and, yet a bit spicy. huge body, creamy and oily texture but flat carbonization. very intensive and long lasting taste. very good, but i like the original aventinus a bit more.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 Bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a rich head. Aroma wheats, caramel, grass. Feels like a strong belgian ale with its hops. The strong alcohol content is very well hidden, but still feels on the tongue. Not Bad.

Bottle. Dark brown with a ghostly white head. Tremendous aroma. Candy banana clove. Irresistable. Delicious wheaty flavour. Hefe characteristics but far more dramatic. Difficult to believe that this was 12%. Lovely stuff.
Wheat, bananas, sweetness and some ass kicking alcohol. This is definitely for keeping warm during these cold winter nghts.

(bottle)  A complex brew compliments of Stoutragious.  Dark complexion with flavors raisins and dried fruits.  Warming alcohol without overpowering.  Belgian style malt & yeast.  A great compliment toward the Oktoberfest Stein!
Raisin brown color with frothy cream head very highly carbonated wonderful aroma notes of fruits and malt prunes figs cloyingly sweet definitely a sipper but well made brew for sure

Bottle. A cloudy dark brown beer, with an average sized, frothy/fizzy, mostly diminishing beige head. The aroma is moderately malty (caramel, toasted bread), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of banana, cloves, cherries, alcohol, plums and figs. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, fizzy carbonation, very long finish with almost medioum bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. Above the average beer, complex, especially in the aroma and a very good sipper, with perhaps only overactive carbonation, but thats a minor complaint, since I do really appreciate beers with active carbonation. I remeber the Aventinus being slightly better, but I think its time to rerate that one.

Aroma and palate are the same as aventinus but multiplied by 1.5. At the same time its twice harder to drink. When it gets warmer it becomes ten times less drinkable. This is not a beer for every day for sure. This is like cognac.

Bread, brown sugar, and caramel in the aroma.  Bread, caramel, toffee, raisins, and banana in the flavor, with some alcohol dryness at the end.   Tremendous.  This might be the best-tasting beer Ive ever tried.

33 cl bottle from Vika Vinmonopolet. Pours murky brown, sparkling with a tan film. Rich spicy, ripe banana caramel nose. Like a mixture of a dunkel-weizen and a quadruppel. Sweet, acidic and a lasting caramel flavored and spicy bitterness. Alco warmth. Full body. Syrupy and doughy. A real winter warmer.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2012 33 cl bottle. Bottled 23.07.2009. BBE 23.07.2014. Bottle #37735.
Deep dark reddish colour with small head. Lots of dark ripe fruits on the nose, caramel, sweet sugary malts, earth, yeast and even berry notes. Flavour has strong ripe fruits, mild toffee, caramel and berries, wheat and spices. Alcohol still strongly present but kind of suits the spectrum of strong flavours nicely.
33 cl bottle. Bottled 05.10.2011. BBE 05.10.2015.
Originally rated on 20090730. (8+4+9+4+16)
Pour murky dark brown colour with medium head. Aroma of ripe fruits, plum, mild raisins, some distant solvent-like alcohol, yeast, basement aromas and some leather. Flavour of ripe fruits, yeast, caramel malts, earth, wheat, plum and some distant notes of spices. Full-bodied and rather complex brew. Some alcohol burn at the end as expected. Not for the faint of heart.
5436

Aroma is rich malts, lots of caramel and toffee, pleasant sweetness and some clove.  Pours amber/brown in color, off-white head with good retention.  Very rich flavor, caramel malts and dark sugars, some molasses, some dark fruits and warming alcohol.  Sweet, but not cloying, very nice flavor profile.  Medium-full body, medium carbonation.  Very nice brew.

Bottle (bottlingdate: 10/09/2010). Drank it at 10 degrees Celsius. Pours cloudy beige/brown which always makes me thirsty. Head disappears soon after pouring but lasts as a very thin layer. Tastes sweet, vinous, thick, complex. Lots of licorice. Lots of dark fruits, like in Christmas pudding. Some vanilla. Some roastiness. Warming mouthfeel (12% ABV). Sweet/roastiness lingering long. Beer is Art!

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Tasted from bottle into nucleated tulip glass. Poured a very dark, opaque brown with serious chill haze and a lively beige head, somewhat lasting with excellent Belgian lace. Much later, a blanket of crowded tiny bubbles still remained, which amazed me considering the very thick body of this beer. If you dislike doppelbock or weizenbock, youll hate this because freeze-distillation removes the water, hence amplifying the aromas and flavors left behind. I for one loved it. Reminiscent of the finest Trappist quadrupels, brown bread, and every type of cooked sugar youve ever tasted: toffee, chocolate, coffee with sugar and cream, caramelized brown sugar, molasses, boiled down maple sugar, candied nuts. There must be some bitterness balancing this beer, because otherwise it would be cloyingly malty-sweet, but very little flavor or aroma hops stand out. You can certainly smell alcohol, but its smooth like quality aged bourbon. Its not until the warmth hits your blood stream that you realize this thing is 12% ABV. Unique and utterly delicious.

Not a big fan. Poured a murky brown it only a touch of brown head. Nose and taste was of wet cardboard, dark fruits, malts, almost no hop profile at all. The mouth feel is a bit over carbonated. I hope this was just a bad bottle but I can only rate what I have in front of me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown with a half inch head that recedes to white lacing.  Aroma of dark cherries that was very noticeable immediately after opening the bottle.  Sour apple is also detectable in the aroma.  Taste is of plums, alcohol, some sourness and some burnt sugar.  I read a few comments from others who said that they felt this beer tasted cloyingly sweet, and I have to say that I did not feel this way at all.  I wonder if those beers were spoiled due to poor shipping or storing.
Dark brown with decent off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, banana, and yeast. Taste is of banana, caramel, malt, yeast, and booze.

Poured from a 11.2 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter. Bottle number 2010 031733 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a dark nutty brown color with ruby highlights and a 1/2 finger bubbly very light tan head. Very little lacing, but thats to be expected at 12% ABV.

Smell: Smells very much like a sweeter version of a weizenbock. Dark fruit is dominant with caramel malt, a touch of clove and just a hint of alcohol.

Taste: Sweet dark fruit and caramel malt up front followed clove and a touch of phenols in the middle before ending with a light bitterness and a touch of medicinal alcohol. Very well-balanced for a beer of this ABV%.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a high amount of prickly carbonation. Feels a bit slick on the tongue. Nice alcohol warmth through the chest after the swallow.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. Goes down easily for a beer this big.

Overall: Very good beer overall. This is my first eisbock and this one has made me curious to check out other beers in the style. Id definitely recommend giving this one a try.

Bottle 33cl. Dark brown beer with a beige and creamy head, good lacing. Taste is malty, sweet, vinous, alcoholic. Tasting this beer results very complex, not only citrus and spicy but also wheat, cinnamon, caramel, fruits are present . On palate results a beer with full body, creamy texture, average carbonation, and long sweet finish. In the aftetaste the sweet character is accentuated. An excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours dark orange/brown with a beige head. Aroma of dark fruit and wheat with roasted malt.  Taste of dark fruit that has been well balanced with the alcohol. some cough syrup taste which is very sweet. Amazing Beer.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2012 lI cracked open the bottle and took a whiff. Wheat was the first, and by far the strongest aroma I picked up. But after pouring it and tasting it, I was pleasantly surprised by its color and taste. Its heavier than most wheat beers Ive had, and on the palate it has the flavor of dried fruit. Very Complex. Very Delicious.

This bottle was shared with zep9865 during our mini tasting before DLD. This beer pours a murky raisin brown with a beige head that laces the glass. Ive had this one before but never reviewed it. This smells super, and syrupy sweet. It wreaks of sweet dark malts, raisins, figs, and light yeast. The nose is even a little sweet for me. This beer is very yeasty and very heavy on the raisins. Wow is it sweet. Its hard to even rate to style when a beer is this sweet. Its borderline cloying. It drinks medium in body but the sweetness prevails above all other aspects. Does this beer taste good? Yes, but in small quantities. The alcohol content doesnt even matter to me because this is super malty (and understandably so) and super fruity. I just cant get past the sweetness. Its a nice style to try but this beer specifically just isnt for me.

Drank at the Weisesbraeuhaus in Muenchen. Very strong but still hides alcohol well. A little alcohol on the nose. Sweet and malty with lots of stone fruits and esters going on. It is a little cloying for me. Otherwise an awesome beer.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Bottle. Pours a near pitch black with a slightly tan head. Surprising carbonation for such a big beer. Nose is spicey with dark fig notes. Flavor.is surprisingly smooth with a big full body. Caramel and dried fruits are prominent. Finishes on the dry side with a little molasses twang. Very good.
Pours a medium brown with some head and little lacing. Nose is boozy malt bomb, first sip is corn sugar, ketones and aldehydes. Finish is warming most pleasant part.

This is terrible. I appreciate the idea but man this is so sweet! its like drinking a sugary liquor. Aroma is bubblegum, banana bread, slight clove spice, maybe cinnamon. Taste is sticky nasty cloying sweet. Puckeringly vomitously sweet. Its like licking sugar dipped babies. Palate is flat and thick. Overall I wont be coming anywhere near this again.

Dark brown/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, clove, bananas, & dark fruit; Flavor of toasted sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums & apricots), bananas, and spice; Alcohol at the finish - but not overpowering; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very good brew.
light sweet aroma, good taste,, best for an after dinner beer- with dessert.

Im not a huge fan of the concept of ice beers, but this is not bad at all. It reeks of alcohol, banana, dark fruits, tons of spices and, well, just all the usual wheat notes but very concentrated, which mixed with the alcohol gives an overripe impression. Obviously when poured it doesnt let as much light through as a its non-iced-out sibling does, which makes it marginally less attractivestill a beautiful beer nonetheless. The taste is very sweet and very sournot my cup of tea, quite frankly, because it is too strong and dominated by alcohol. The mouthfeel is mainly syrupy and alcoholic, with some carbonation. The wheat is there, but it isnt the main attraction. It may sound as if I didnt like this beer, but I actually thought it was really goodbut Id much rather have a regular Aventinus.
Bottle. Aroma of dark ripe fruits, with wheat and malt. Very sweet, then bit of acid and tanginess. Light hoppiness, though mild. Moderate aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2011 "Eisbock" is a term that can refer to either a specific style of very strong lager or a brewing technique. According to RateBeer.com the eisbock style is defined as "A stronger version of Doppelbock. Deep copper to black. Very alcoholic. Typically brewed by freezing a doppelbock and removing resulting ice to increase alcohol content." So when a brewery uses the term "Eisbock" in the name of the beer its easy to assume its a lager. But in the case of Schneider Aventinus Weizen Eisbock it refers to the brewing technique of freezing the beer - as this beer is simply Schneider Aventinus Weizenbock (a strong wheat beer) that was frozen to increase the alcohol percentage even further. The result is a very complex and tasty beer - I cant wait to try the non-frozen version!I poured an 11.2oz bottle into a snifter (dated 2009)Appearance: Very barleywine-like with a deep purple or maroon color; totally opaque; forms a small, yellow sudsy head which dissipates quickly and completely.Smell: Like spiked fruit punch - a mélange of various fruits with noticeable alcohol presence. Very sweet-smelling - nothing acidic or tart to the nose.Taste: I wasnt sure what to expect with Schneider Aventinus Weizen Eisbock as Ive never had the regular Weizenbock that this brew is derived from. The palate here was definitely in two distinct stages: up front is a remarkably sweet taste of fruit punch and jam, plus red grape, raspberry, and Macintosh apple. It has the sweetness of a complex barleywine or a Belgian quadruple, but a much thinner, lighter body - nothing sticky or syrupy here. The second half changes on a dime and reveals the booziness of the beer. Rubbing alcohol dryness, taste, and heat emerge as does significant carbonation and fizziness. As it warms, the two halves merge together. Its still sweet and fruity but with a bitter, slightly tart and acidic overtone. Whats interesting is that for a wheat-based beer theres nothing wheaty here at all (although I have friends who tried a fresh bottle who say theres lots of banana and clove in the palate). Mouthfeel: For such a big beer its amazing its noticeably thin and highly carbonated - even after warming up and calming down. Surprisingly clean aftertaste - no residual sweetness or dryness.Drinkability: Weighing in at 12% ABV, Schneider Aventinus Weizen Eisbock is no session beer, obviously. The best way to describe it would be "fizzy barleywine." It has the complex, rich, sweet flavors found in those bigger ales, but with the lighter, thinner and fizzy mouthfeel and drinkability of a lager (even though its an ale). It can be drank quickly or slowly without much affect on the palate or loss of drinkability. A great beer to pair with any kind of berry cheesecake.Overall, this is a very unique and fun beer to drink, although I dont think Id want to drink it all the time. Its definitely a beer for special occasions.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a deep amber color with thin but dense head of tan foam.  The nose is full of dried fruit, some yeast, and port notes.  The flavor carries the same notes as the nose.  Raisin, date, port, and a slight dark wheat note.  Surprisingly light on the tongue given its strength.  I would say medium bodied but the combination of wheat and alcohol dry things out on the back end making it seem lighter.  Really a great brew and a must try.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. Aroma of burned caramel and coffee. Taste is pleasantly bitter, rich, full-bodied. A very good beer.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with dark brown head. Sharp strong aroma of dried fruit, yeast, alcohol, bananas. Taste is dried fruit, grapes, alcohol.

Bottle at Schneider bar. Pours dark dark brown with tan head. Aroma dark fruits with banana and cloves. Taste is the same, dark fruits up front, raisins, plumb, subsides to wheat beer banana and clove notes. Bit like a belgian quad crossed with a wheat beer. Had much more carbonation than I was expecting. Incredibly complex.

(Bottle 0,33l)
Strong fruit, strong plums and raisins, light caramel sweet, light spicy aroma. Cloudy red-brown color. Quickly done head. Very sweet, strong fruity, spicy taste. Really full body. Very sticky texture. Strong alcohol warm, dry finish... Very good beer. Shame that it is so alcoholic. The palete is really good, but that alcohol aftertaste spoils it for me. I know it is the meaning of this style, but it annoys me. Taste is also too sweet and there is no bitterness to balance it. I was also disappointed by its head...

Starker hefiger Geruch mit Einflüssen von Gewürznelke. Die erwartete Alkoholfahne ist anfangs nur leicht ausgeprägt. Später ist der Alkohol dann sehr deutlich zu riechen. Süßlich-malziger Antrunk. In der Mitte wirkt das Bier nussig und kräuterig. Hier beginnt auch der Einfluß des Alkohols auf den Geschmack, wenn auch noch moderat. Im Abschied schwer malzig und auf der Zunge brennend alkoholisch - lange nachwirkend. 
Leider schränkt der enorme Alkoholgehalt den Geschmack ein. Als Digestiv jedoch akzeptabel.Test vom 31.3.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Bottle, pours dark brown with small white head... the aroma is banana, wheat, flowers, caramel, resin.... the flavor is banana, wheat, alcohol, caramel..... very nice tasty mouthful, thick body..... fresh with nice finish.... this is one you have to taste.....

Pours brown with a beige head.  Aroma is clove, caramel, raisin and some banana.  Taste is sweet with a silky amooth finish.  The alcohol is well hidden and only become noticeable as the beer warms.  Excellent.

Bottle.Pours cloudy brown with an off-white head.Aroma of alcohol, malt, caramel,yellow apples and malt.Flavor is sweet caramel, wheat and malt with some warming notes and spice.Medium to full body, soft carbonation.A really nice beer.

Pours muddy brown with virtually no head. Smells strongly malty with notes of banana and clove underneath with hints of alcohol. Tastes like an overly malted hefeweizen or an overly wheated dopple/eisbock; very complex and different, with lots of wheat, strong malts, banana and clove, and lots of alcohol. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and little mouth-carbonation (though it is quite carbonated in the glass), Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock finishes with a touch of sweetness and alcohol burn.

Bottle from Appellation. Pours a cloudy brown colour. A thin light tan head with big bubbles. Aroma of bready yeast, alcohol, caramel, treacle and rum & raisin chocolate. Fruity flavour of prunes, raisins, some caramel and lingering warming alcohol. Moderate carbonation with mild CO2 prickle. An exceptional beer.

Bottle @ Dans house. Cloudy brown appearance with a light brown head. Really a nice, toasty, dark wheat malty aroma with some banana and clove. Absolutely delicious toasty dark wheat malty, toffee, slight chocolate flavor with some notes of dark banana bread. This is awesome!

Pours hazy reddish brown with white head. Aroma is some nice toffee, raisin, chocolate, touch of vanilla, some slight earth and spice notes. Taste is notes of vanilla and toffee, some slight dark fruit, cocoa powder, finishing a bit too sweet but tasty.

(Bottle) Dark brown colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of dried fruit, raisins, over ripe banana, clove, treacle, citrus peel, dried apricots and toffee. Quite estery and vinous. Fruity, malty taste with dried fruit, raisins, cherries in brandy, dark bread, mashed banana with chocolate sauce, treacle, citrus, dried apricots, herbs and spices (clove, cinnamon). Vinous and warming finish. More than medium body, fairly sweet. Smooth and slightly oily. Lovely beer.

11.2 oz bottle.
Amber brown brew with some nice off-white head.  I probably smelled this 10 times before I took my first stip - dark fruit, wheat, clove and other spices.  ABV is quite well hidden with flavors of banana, more dark fruit, and lots of malt.  Became more complex as it warmed.
Cloudy dark amber / brownish, off-white head. Smell malts, wheat and a slight sweetness. Ok taste, medium to full body, medium carbo.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2012 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours opaque light brown with floating chunks of yeast and small beige head.  Great lacing, medium body, and medium carbonation.  Taste is caramel, fig, and rasian malt, candy sugar, and warming alcohol.  Good, reminds me of a quadruple.

Pours opaque brown with a thick tan head...lots of sediment throughout.  Aroma is somewhat sweet...raisins, faint clove, yeasty...shellfish note...reminds me of a dubbel.  Flavor follows suit...much like a dubbel and with some dry, earthy characteristics.  Mouthfeel is silky and cream with a very warming finish.
8oz wooden cask serving. Smooth as silk. Candy sweet and slightly tropical.
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012 Rerating 6.1.2012. Greyish brown, no head. Strong flavour of bananas and alcohol. Viscous. Oily, almost greasy. Some other fruit to be noticed.

33 cL bottle at the Schneider Weisse Brauhaus in Munich, served a distinctive glass of its own.  Dark brown with a creamy head.  Nice wheat and caramel aroma.  Probably the smoothest 12% beer going.  Wheat, caramel and some alcohol.  A bit fizzy.

33 cl bottle vintage 2009, nr. 37615, BBE 23.07.14
A foam that disappears immediately. Aroma is alcohol, very ripe banana and some berry bush. Alcohol burns my tongue. Flavour has some very ripe fruits and some alcohol. Still, rather enjoyable stuff despite of the alcohol. Worse than the original though.

Dark brown/ copper with white head. Banana, clove, bready malts, apple cider, boozy. Similar to a quad with a splash of booze added. A big beer. Good but i wasnt in love with it and probably wouldnt buy it again.

Tasted on 7/22/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors, bottled in 2010.  Pours murky dark brown with a thick, fizzy, beige head that recedes to nothing more than a thin collar of lace.  The nose is super intense with alcoholic heat, sweet caramel, maple syrup, cola, dark dried fig and prune, and just a hint of some lightly burnt bitterness.  The flavor is a bit darker some chocolate in addition to the caramel, cola, and sweet maple malt, along with the intense alcoholic heat, dried fig and prune, and some almost burnt bitter malt.  The body is full, nearly cloyingly so, with light carbonation and a super long cola, maple, and dried fruit finish.

Bottle 330ml @ yngwie
Pours cloudy dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wheat and banana. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle shared with esp0r at Grünerløkka Brygghus.
It has a dark red, brownish color, and a soft tanned head.
Sweet aroma with wheat, yeast, gum and marcipan.
Strong complex malty taste with all kinds of fruits, spices and banana. 
Its quite nice, and has a warm lasting finish
Fresh very fruity aroma. Great fruity taste, apple juice, raisins and warming alcohol. A clearly surprising taste and a very good one! Perfect to sit back and sip on!
So good! Reminds me of a quad but its not. Aroma of belgian wheat with a nuanced flavor of fruits, sweet malty lining and flowery tinge with candy sweetness in the finish.

Bottle shared with Daje at Grünerløkka Brygghus
Deep red, big tanned head. Aroma of banana, malts and yeast esters. Body is winy, some banana and citrus too. Full malt flavor of course, its a bock. Good sweetness too. Amazing how nice this beer actually is. Feel is quite thick, almost oily. Finish has also good bitterness. This could be a nice beer to enjoy late in fall by the fire actually.

Same colour as tawny port with evident carbonation,creamy white head that subsides. Smells of allspice, christmas cake, plum wine, cinnamon and burnt sugar. Then theres vinous notes of sherry (pedro ximinex where the grape juice has had brandy added and thats it). Strong and complex aromas. I think Ive only ever given one 10 for aroma before.
Good God. Those same aromas appear in excelsis along with classic German yeastiness. Wow. This beer is a very heavy hitter.
500ml bottle. Very unfiltered, like floaties unfiltered. Complex flavour, a little bit of everything, but still remains balanced. The 12% ABV is not as noticeable as it should be.

Sampled at SIB. Pours a cloudy, solid, dirty brown. Aroma of caramel malts, wheat, banana. Flavour is of caramel malts, wheat, hay, booze, grass and banana. Incredibly well balanced and highly complex. Beautiful.

Bottle from Chans in Panama City.  Cola looking pour.  Strong tobacco and dark fruit aroma.  Big taste too - dark fruit, caramel, banana and chocolate.  Clean and even throughout.  Not to my tastes exactly, but a very high quality brew.

Very sweet caramelly bready aroma, banana, spicey yeast.  Has a very viscous, syrupy body with extremely high sweetness.  I did like the caramel and toasts notes of this along with the banana and clove flavors that I havent previously encountered in this style.  Interesting, but with the sugar content it was hard to even finish my four ounces.

Firm head over a cloudy brwn body. Hazelnuts, earthy, rasberry, alcohol, raisin and cereal. Body has some sweetness first but is dry overall. To the end it becones quite alcoholic, like a herbal distillate or snapss. Interesting and unusual, but with rough (alcoholic) edges. More a curiousity in the end than a beer Id like more often. (33cl bottle)

330 mL bottle. Pours a dark, hazy orange with a medium tan head. The aroma is strong, dark fruits, caramel, apples, earthy and citrus hops, and bubblegum. The flavor is intense malts and light hop bitterness. The palate is very heavy, thick and slightly astringent. The finish is long and sticky, with significant alcohol warming. Overall, a blunt and powerful beer. Very little subtlety, which isnt really the point, I guess.

Has virtually the strength and character of a great barley-wine, but with the flavors of a fine wheat beer. Take the standard Aventinus, which is amazing/unique in its own right, bring the intensity of everything up a notch, and this weizen-eisbock is where you arrive. Light, pleasant aromas of caramel, brown toffee, raspberries, and fresh wheat bread. The pour is dark brown with a persistent off-white head and minimal lacing. Rich and malty, but sparkly on the tongue, with a slight sourness following honey, dark wheat bread, hickory, black pepper, and nearly imperceptible hop bitterness. Ends a bit contradictory: sweet and dry, with a bit of an alcohol burn. This might be my favorite weizen.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 Bottle at North Bar, Leeds. My my, this ones special. Hazy, orangey copper colour. Big, impressive aroma, with chocolate, alcohol, spice, red fruit and a bit of germen yeastiness. Beautifully blended, sweet spiciness, with hints of caramel, chocolate, dark fruits and esteriness. Alcohol not too noticeable in the taste, but warming in the throat (but not burning) - its very taste-oriented. Finish is rewardingly long and warming. Very enjoyable on lots of levels, this is absolutely delicious.

Pours a murky brown with generous head.  Aroma is banana bread, banana liqueur, and freshly cut banana with a hint of spice.  Taste is super intense spicy and tangy wheat bread followed by alcohol warmth and a woody banana finish.  This brew is medium bodied with fizzy carbonation.  Literally swells up in the mouth like champagne and finishes loooong.  Overall, another very interesting brew that is best shared with others.  This one bottle will get you solidly buzzed.

Shared bottle at North Bar, Leeds. Hazy copper/murky brown poor with orange highlights. Nose is big - some chocolate, some red fruit, bit of alcohol, plenty of German hefe spice, too. Palate is sweet but smooth, hint of chocolate, lots of caramel and ester, with a rich, sweet, warming finish. Pretty high carbonation but overall very smooth and masks the alcohol pretty well. Really nice.
(bottle) hazy dark brown. Aroma of dark fruit, yeast, some clove. Flavor is dark fruit, banana, clove, yeast and alcohol. Im not a huge weissbier fan, and this is a dunkleweiss in droves.

Bottle from Redmonds, Dublin. Drunk watching Man Utd get taught a lesson by Barcelona in the CL final. Hazy dark brown pour with an off white head.  Great nose of dark fruit, christmas cake, spices, vanilla and banana. Loads packed in there. Flavour contained similar elements, with prominent sweet fruit and malts and a reasonably hefty warming booze hit. In addition there was a pleasant earthy qualty and some chocolate and nut notes..  Very tasty stuff. Probably one of the best German brews Ive tasted thus far.
Very sweet beer, with the alcohol coming through quite strongly - as youd expect when its 12%. Malty beer with hint of strawberries and vanilla - really enjoyable.

Bouteille de 500ml. Bière ambrée foncée avec une mousse blanche. Le nez de cette bière est merveilleux, des arômes de toffee, de caramel, de blé, de banane (levure), dalcool, noisette. En bouche la bière est chaleureuse, mentholé, sucre dorge. Leffervescence rend la bière en bouche expansive. La banane est perceptible en bouche. Lalcool chaud provoque une douceur sous les yeux. Latténuation rend ce monstre à 12,0% très digeste, cest dangereux. Jaimerais la boire côte à côte avec lAventinus. Schneider est mon meilleur brasseur allemand et une fois de plus il ne me déçoit pas. 9/10 (merci Patrick)

Bottle @ Home. Pours slightly hazy dark brown with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of malt, ripe dark fruit, caramel, wheat, some yeast.  Taste is wheat, yeast, malt, banana, plums, caramel, cloves, brown sugar. Medium to full body, low carbonation, slight boozy finish. Very nice beer. 111011

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2016 Poured cola-black with a 1/2 finger head.  not much carbonation here.  Aroma of cloves, Banana, spices, a very slight hint of nutmeg.  Flavor of banana and cloves, dried dark fruit, wheat, molasses, burnt caramel, bubble gum and a bit of alcohol- theres a lot happening here.  Fairly heavy in the mouthfeel.  Definitely one to sip considering its ABV.  Well made and one that Iook forward having to anytime the seasons change.

Sehr fruchtiger Geruch, der nach und nach ins hefige umschlägt. Dunkler Malzantrunk, in dem sich der Alkohol zeigt. Dies ist nicht wirklich störend, verhindert aber das durchdringen anderer erahnbarer Aromen wie Schokolade. Im mittelteil dagegen stört der Alkohol schon, er ist hier mit säuerlichem Beiton zu stark. Im Nachgeschmack fällt zuerst die aus dem Mittelteil bekannte alkoholisch-säuerliche Note auf, bei der hier allerdings ein klebriger Schokoladenton erkennbar ist. Etwas entäuscht bin ich schon, ich hätte ein etwas komplexeres Bier erwartet, bei dem der Alkohol nicht so stark im Vordergrund steht, wie es hier der Fall ist. Das "normal" Aventinus ist mir lieber! 	 
Test vom 19.2.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 13,9,8,12,13,11 - 10,70
33cl bottle at home. Malt alcohol and dark fruit aromas, plum/prune/grape flavors in medium body with slight tautness from alcohol. Spiciness due to wheat in grainbill and/or yeast-derived.

This one is a treat. Pleasant on every scale. Nice brown color with a medium head. Aroma of dark fruits, chocolate and malt. Flavor of cherries, prunes, chocolate, malt and caramels. Nice alcohol finish. This beer is a treat.

Amazingly strong beer.
Love the aromas tha jump out and the sweetness that the taste leaves at the end. If you plan to drink it...then take your time and you will find your self in a journey of taste knowledge.

Bottle. Pours red-brown with a tenacious, fine-grained head. Usual banana and clove suspects on the nose, with chocolate and lactic notes. Drinks sweet and strong -- theres definitely some booziness, but theres also cocoa and milky notes that smooth it out. along with a bizarre apple cider element. Finish is clean, but lingers. Not an everyday beer, but a fun change.

What a wonderful beer.  My first beer love was Aventinus so it is no wonder that I loved this concentrated version.  It was everything I dreamed of with less alcohol taste than expected for 12%.  Weizen-bocks are amazing beers.  I would really like to see a barrel aged version...

Le liquide a une robe brune.  La petite mousse se transforme en anneau.  Au nez, des effluves dalcool sentremêlent avec des parfums de fruits secs, des épices et des arômes de céréales maltées rôties.  Les saveurs sont bien peu éloignées du bouquet avec des raisins goûteux et des bananes mûres qui baignent dans une base maltée sucrée et alcoolisée.  Également, bon retour dépices et de notes de blé sur les papilles.  En bouche, le liquide me semble bien dense avec son effervescence modérée et sa texture épaisse.  En finale, un souffle chaud qui se plaît à secouer toute cette richesse maltée.  En résumé, nourrissant.

Deep red-amber with brown overtones.  Dark fruit, banana, clove, sweet wheat malt.  Complex flavor - candied dark fruits, banana, clove, mild roasted malt.  Thick and sticky on the palate, booze semi-well-hidden.  Pow!
Sickly sweet and very thick molasses. Banana flavored medicine perhaps?

Aroma has both red berries but also a real white. Murky red brown appearance, not very beautiful. 
Taste also has a lot of red fruit (raspberry, red berries). Palate is smooth, very warming beer, really good beer.
Bottle at Menno Boorsma, Amsterdam

Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock is the type of beer youd like to drink after falling into a frozen lake.  Which may count as irony, but Im not sure.  (What the hell was I doing during all those English classes?  Oh yeah.  Drugs.)  Looks like a weizenbock on steroids and anti-schizophrenia pills, almost aping a porter, save the tan line at the bottom of the glass.  And, surprise, surprise, it tastes like a weizenbocks gymrat older brother.  You get the banana-n-cloves flavor, but a darker, meatier version, like brandied banana-cloves in a bowl of grain alcohol, like someone bottled up the fire in you parents bedroom on Christmas Eve when you were nine;  its comforting and laced with expectant anxiety.  To be savored slowly, for sure.  Bonus points for anyone who considers this lawnmower beer.   (12/4/08)

500ml bottle.  Pours a clear dark reddish brown with a beige head.  Aroma has VERY evident alcohol, yeast, banana, faint cherry, and dried fruits.  Taste is very heavy on dried fruits, impressively so.  Sweet, with molasses, dark malts, again dried fruits aplenty, and a finish of alcohol and dried cherries.  A BIG beer in every way.  This is going to knock me on my a@#.  Impressive.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 This is still my current all-time favorite beer -  the one to have if youre having only one.  Ive never attempted drinking more than one of these in a week and will not reward myself with one if Ive had a bad week.   It pours a dark purplish brown but opaque color. The smell is dark fruity,  Fortunately, it is not a banana beer, nor can it be compared to regular bock beers.  I taste dark fruits (raisins, cloves, figs?)  It packs a wallop, since water/ice was removed from the normal bock beer to make this..  The taste is sweet, with no alcohol burn.  It is definitely meant to be sipped.   I should be working now but I had one of these two hours ago and have been spending time reading other reviews of this ever since.

Dark brown, an ok holding and sticking head. Good smell of wheats, a bit fruity touch and also some light sweetness gets trough. Light sweet fruity taste, caramel, wheats, good spiced. Pretty decent beer for sure. Sweet, but not overdone. Wheat-taste holds very good, and in combine with the ftuitiness pretty good. Some raisins, and pretty yeasty.

Molasses level sticky sweet.  I dont know about this one; its very noticeable that this is higher abv, it is cloying, and it lacks any hop bite or yeast complexity.  Really just not great; like an inferior version of Doppelsticke.
UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 2009 bottle. Aroma of dark fruits and banana. Taste follows through with perfect carbonation; very rich flavor. Great beer.

Bottle. Dark brown color with little foam. More malts in aroma. Alcohol in flavor. Raisins in flavor. Beer like Estonian home-made fruit wine. Blackberry- apple wine, may be. Interesting. Worth to taste it.

Pours a deep brown with a full and frothy foamy head.  Sweet bananas and raisins initially.  Caramel candy, chocolate, and a nice bread-like yeasty quality all come into play as well.  Rich caramel, bananas, raisins, yeast, and a light touch of apple on the palate.
Draft. Rich black color. No head. Smells of berrues, syrup and fruit. Really comples and good

Very dark in colour.  Similar taste and aroma to its non-eis equivalent, though with less banana and more alcohol.  The dark colour and the high alcohol content/taste remind me of an extra strong trappist ale.
Poured cloudy purple smelled wheaty and sour tasted about the same betteerb than expected great beer

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours an opaque amber-copper colour with a big, fluffy white head. The nose has a huge emphasis on sweet fruits and wheat. Banana, cloves and raisins combine in the flavours to produce an excellent beer. One of my favourite belgians

Bottled from Bierzwerg. Dark cloudy brown color with small beige head. Aroma, caramel, fruit, roasted bread. Taste, sweet, raisins, dried red fruit, orange and banana. Nice dry finish. Excellent beer.

I quite liked this one, same bottle as pictured, it pours a dark colour, cant see through this one, it was sweet with tastes of banana almost and it had a nice finish, good offering would drink again
Pours dark amber with lots of tan head. Aroma is chocolate and banana. Lingering aftertaste with strong alcoholic flavor. Not as tasty as its kid brother.

Pours a dark brown color that surprised me!  Wasnt expecting this color at all.  Has a small off white head that appears quite creamy.  Smells of chocolate, butter and wheat.  Taste is yummy.  i taste what I was smelling with a creamy finish.  Mmm.

11.2 oz bottle into my Rochefort glass...Good lacing on this brew, a dark translucent copper...Aroma is strong sweet wheat from start to finish, a hint of alcohol but pretty plain...The taste is awesome, super complext so much is going on here. Starts off lightly sweet then a super smooth but strong wheat taste laced with a hint of malty backbone and alcohol....Feel is nice, super smooth to drink nice slightly warm finish....Incredibly easy to drink at 12%.

This is one fantastic beer, quite easily one of my favorite Germans. Well worth trying.

330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is banana, clove, raisin and a little alcohol.  Taste is banana and alcohol to start.  Banana, raisin and clove on the finish.  Lots of booze on the aftertaste.  Complex.

im not even sure what to write about this one, reminds me of when i rated an apt/quad before i had any idea about beer, way too much too soon. I havent felt this way in a long time, but i think most people would have this reaction after tasting this one. there are the common hefeweizen characteristics with added abv obviously, but also dark fruit, and a hint of mint maybe. its really complex, maybe one of the most complex beers ive ever had, and one that should not be tasted lightly, mentally prepare yourself for this one cause its a big beer.
Sweet roasty, strong fruit-raspberry aroma.  Deep brown with a light tan head.   Sweet and roatsy with slightly chocolatey and raspberry sweet.  I strong dark beer.

Bottle. Finger of tan head on a very dark muddy brown.  Aroma features loads of green apples cinammon and cloves with some light yeastiness. Apples, caramel, and a warming touch of alcohol dominate the taste, but with some mint coming in at the end.  Thicker body with suprisingly vibrant carbonation.  Nice
Its all about the fig for me. in aroma and taste. It was the 2009 filling.

0.33l bottle. Pours a dark grey-brown body with a small grey head. Nose is yeast, sweet alcohol, wheat, rhubarb and cloves. Lively carbonated and medium bodied. Tastes at first some sweet green banana, cloves, yeast and almonds before the stingy and warming alcohol vanishes down the throat. Good boozy finish with hints of some red fruit. Apple perhaps? Sounds kinda strange, but for me this tastes like easter. Quite nice and highly drinkable.
alcohol, bread, brown, hazy, brown foam, medium bitterness, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long alcohol finish.
At a tasting, bottle, pours cloudy light brown, strong alcohol, strong Bazooka gum and sour aroma, full and good body, and overall a great beer.
33 bottle shared with friends.  Alchohol in the aroma, sickly sweet flavor with definite banana taste.

33cl bottle shared with friends.
Hazy dark beer. Bananas in the aftertaste. A bit sweet, should age nicely
Crazy-strong fruit taste, just overpowering.  Very heavy on the AC.  This is a celebratory beer for a reason.

12/03/2011 - 33cl bottle @ home (2011-114)  Thanks to Klaas for the bottle! 
Little cloudy dark brown beer. Light beige head, dissipates quickly. Aroma: yeast, alcohol, ripe fruits. Taste: very fruity, chocolate, bit sour, forest fruits, yeast. Aftertaste: fruity, caramel and toffee.

Pours a deep brown to mahogany.  White, four finger head.  Decent lacing.

Smells like chocolate bread with berries.  Yeasty, thick, bready, and malty.  Like a beer milkshake.

Wow the taste is complex.  Thick and bready but clean.  Chocolate and raspberries.  Its almost like a dessert quad.  Lots of different flavors come together.  Pumpernickel, chocolate, raspberries, blackberries, wheat toast, toffee, caramel.  Not overly rich.  Smooth and creamy.  Just delicious.

Hides its high abv very well.  I have to say it again:  dessert quad.  Easy to drink and leaves me wanting more.

Pours a beautiful mahogany. Very clear. Pure white head that slowly falls into a nice collar. Clean nose of spice, banana. Malt smells like your in the middle of a wheat field. Well rounded mouthfeel fills the mouth and coats the tongue. The alcohol comes through in a nice, subtle manner.  Fruit and esters permeate. Great beer.

Strong banana, ester aroma coming off this.    Dark amber and orange color thats initially murky but becomes crystal clear as it warms up.   Sweet, malty goodness followed by a combination of banana, molasses, caramel and butterscotch.  Some combination of hop and roasted malt bitterness wraps this up so the sweetness doesnt get too out of control.  This is one delicious beer!
dratf. my first eisbock, pretty decent taste,strong with nice head and palate. good one.
bottle - hazy brownish beer with a thin beige head. Fruity banana aroma. Flavour is complex with a caramel note which hides the high alcohol. Low but decent bitterness. Medium carbonation.
UPDATED: JUL 13, 2015 Banoffee pie aroma - very enticing. Full structure on the palate and firm texture. More bananas and toffee with a bit of alcohol burn on the finish.

Dark brown with a fast disappearing off-white head. Aroma is sweet, dried fruit, banana, yeasty and spicy - cloves. Flavor is very sweet. Soft and smooth with a sweet finish. The alcohol is not only warming my throat but my cheeks as well. Complex and excellent brew on a cold day. 240211

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2017 3 Jan 2016, bottle. hazy, brown. nose is boozy, banana, red fruit. i think there is a lot here but it is hard to put my finger on it. Its bold and in your face and the alcohol is hard to get past. but there is definitely more banana in this than in the Aventinus. med body and moderately fizzy. dry and yet syrupy. much more flavorful than the Aventinus. Sweet, banana, alcohol, some leather or wood. nice. 

Original rating Feb 24, 2011 (6 3 7 3 13 = 3.2)
light brown/gold colour, hazy w/ steady bubbles
lovely sweet raisin and alcohol smell w/ a bit of sourness as well
med/thin body and mildly fizzy
bread and raisin pudding

This is a massive flavour bomb.  My goodness.  Pours a dark reddish-brown with mountains of foam.  Explosive aromas: plum, bread, berry.  I get a strong brandy-like character.  Its almost too much.  Alcohol is pretty mind-blowing but that means the flavour hangs on forever.  An experience thats for sure.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 Oh brother was this too good. This has a lot going for it. Of course the color is its first notable distinction, but it doesnt end there. After you are done gazing upon the beautiful ruby setting and its light fawn head. The real treat begins. I dont want to spoil it completely for those of you who relish surprise, but it is full bodied with black cherry and  other dark fruits. Thats all I will say. Get one if you see it on the shelf.
The boozy nose and bosy take away from the complexity of this lager, very interesting structure it is just masked with alcohol, too bad
Excellent aroma of caramel, maybe molasses. Alcohol is present, but not overwhelming. Would buy again for sure.

Deep, dark, mahogany in color with a short lived, tan head.  MONSTER AROMA of rich fruit cake, molasses and a touch of booze.  The flavor is intense in a umami kind of way.  Light alcohol, dark sugary molasses, dates, and figs.  The carbonation is enough to keep this beer feeling relatively light and quite drinkable. I keep thinking that a pot roast with brown gravy would be sublime with this.  What a superb drinking experience.  I can only imagine this fresh.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black. Nose of plum, prune, banana, toffee, dark caramel, chocolate, clove and dark fruit. Taste is wheat, grain alcohol, prune, dark fruit, clove, banana and plum.

Aroma of dark fruit mainly raisins, touch spicy, bready, dark malt, and cloves. Pour brown with a hue of red, 2 finger beige head that disappeared quick. Taste big hit of spice, cloves, breadiness, yeast, dark malt and sweet candy sugar. Mouth feel a tad syrupy with mild carb. Great beer needs a bit more age before a crack another tasty none the less.

22/01 0.33 l bottle at Glockl Brau, Graz, actually didnt see the bottle. It poured slightly hazy dark brown body with medium sized brownish head. Dark sweet malt aroma, caramel, dried fruits and chocolate while weizen notes contribute with yeasty heavy cloying scent. Alcohol is also felt here. Flavor was even better, all the mentioned bits are even more prominent, except alcohol which is mostly hidden, until the very end. As you drink it more, becomes more complex as subtle things emerge making a full palette of sweet dark malt and weizen yeast flavors. Full bodied with long, beautifully balanced finish, sweetish. Alcohol is evident but not too much, its easily drinkable. Wonderful indeed, almost perfect.

Bottle #063233

I have been cellaring this for a little while on my own, I cant tell if its a vintage but I dont believe it is, Ive finally unleashed it since I received the Aventinus Eisbock glass.

Upon first look into bottle all you see is black, that is about to change, so I pop it open.

After pouring it into the official glass with a 2 finger tan head that dissipates quickly it is very dark but has a brownish reddish hue in the thinner parts of the glass and along the sides that makes for viewing wonder. The yeast continuously funnels its way to the top, this thing wont stop bubbling. The yeast itself is a wonder with this beer. Im not sure if this particular glass shape lends itself to the active yeast but it is a great looking and feeling glass to drink out of and I highly recommend getting one to try this beer with.

Massive amount of scents here, Ive got some herbalness, fruitiness, and even some sourness in the nose. Soft clove and raisin are the main scent hits.

First taste. Woooow, creamy, smooth, with enough bite from the yeast, heaps of flavors begin to spill out, coffee, chocolate, raisin, clove, honey, the yeast adds a bit of tartness and the aftertaste is of ripe fruit. This is a malty beer through and through and is like a total bier dessert. As it warms the yeast mellows out and the full flavor effect is reached. The last drop (gulp) was insanely yeast infested and was like the grand finale, maybe not the best part, but a taste experience nonetheless. And Im not even tasting the alcohol in here one bit. This beer is highly drinkable despite its array of potent flavors, but it is best enjoyed with smaller sips.

This beer went great with chocolate truffles, dark cherries and to a lesser extent Assiago cheese.

Overall this is one of my favorites, full bodied, full flavored, and full strength. It is well worth the money and then some.

Godlike.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Come on now this is fantastic. No heavy machinery after this one. Good stuff. Strong, tasty, rich, alc. warmth. all that kind of thing. Serving: Bottle
Chestnut brown color with an aroma of plums, bananas and bread.  Quite dry with plums, bananas, clove, and wheat flavors.  Definitive alcohol presence.  Warms you on a cold day.  Very nice.

Pours chestnut. Terrific beight head, with good retention and considerable lace. Aroma-wise, this one is boozy like theres not tomorrow. Otherwise, its all about the cereals and the yeast. This said, I had a cold, so I cant say much more. Taste is grapes and banana galore! Some clove as well. Less boozy than what aroma would suggest, but still boozy. To a certain extent, it really tastes like a boozier Aventinus, only with a bigger emphasis on the dark fruits and a lesser emphasis on banana. Not much in the way of hops. Sticky mouthfeel, perfect sugar balance, which is impressive considering how low on hops this one is. Yeast job? Maybe. Finale is rather long, but smooth. All in all, this one is not as good overall as the Aventinus. But, as a winter warmer, its as good as it can possibly get.

330ml Bottle.  Pours a deep brown, almost black color with effervescent off-white head.  Aroma is rich with dried fruits, yeast, and bread.  The taste is huge dried fruits, plum, raisin with typical Weizen banana and a big cereal malt flavor.  Alcohol flavor is very strong but well matched with the big malt taste.  Palate is full-bodied and thick with a long-lasting malty aftertaste.  Wonderful beer.
Like regular Aventinus, only much stronger.  The alcohol takes over and detracts from it slighly, mainly because it diminishes the dark malt/banana flavors.

The quality doesnt lack here. A dark brown beer with an average light brown head. Aroma is rich, full of banana, plums, raisin, bread and dried fruits hints. Taste is quite long with a well balanced sweet/bitter mouthfeel.
Some obviously acidic sour note from the style.
Really good.
Bottled.  Its too damned dark at rabbit club to see the coloration.  Nose is yeast and bananas esters. Sip is acidic and sour.  Alco is noticeable but not so for 12 percent.  Good but not my cup.

First rating of an eisbock.  11.2 ounce bottle purchased at World Market ($3.99).  Bottle says that it was made in 2009.  Pours a deep murky burgundy hue yeast sediment and two fingers of beige head.  Aroma of rich caramel, nice fruity esters (plum and some banana creme), chocolate, sweet wheat, and some dusty spice.  Flavor is more of the same with very nice (not overly sweet) caramel notes, dark ripe fruit, and spice.  This big beer is incredibly smooth in the mouth and has a near-perfect level of sweetness and strength.  The high alcohol is well hidden.  A really stellar brew.  (1283, 445)

A - very full and dark amber color with dark orange tones
S - very intensive and pleasant smell of banana and wild-rose
T - extraordinary banana start with great mixture of wild-rose and caramel and very nice carbonation and full mouthfeel ending pretty dry and not so hoppy, but the presence of yeast is awesome. Alcohol is perfectly hidden in the beer.
M - full body with brilliant carbonation
D - very drinkable, however very strong, so be careful.

This eisbock is totally great.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2016 Geur heeft brodige mout, pruim en caramel... smaak heeft veel donker zoet fruit... zachte warme body


black redish beer, big plummy head, foams like a bitch... aroma is really malty, a bit fruit, dens but not overly complex, some alchohol shones through...taste is sweet, there?s some exotic fruit, lots of malts, some hops... finish is long and big, sweet and bitter, warm and alcpholic... this is a big beer, very heavy in the mouth, very lively, foams when drinking... first sips are pretty common, but halfway trough this beer it becomes really good... 12% alchohol, you notice it yes, but you?de never say there is that much in it....

500ml bottle sample purchased at the LCBO. Pours a very dark cloudy brown. with no real head to speak of. I didnt really notice any lacing either. Aroma is flowery and of dark fruit like raisins. The taste is blissfully of dark fruit again, and an aftertaste that numbs the tongue a little. This beer reminds me of a trappist beer, Rochefort in particular. This beer is awesome.
Freeze out the water and eisbock you have! Tried on draft. Incredibly smooth, very flavorful & complex. True Bavarian Hefe and then some (abv+++). Worth its weight in gold and one of my favorites.

12 %-os alkoholtartalma szinte eltörpül a hihetetlen erős és koncentrált gyümölcsíz mellett. Alkoholba mártott túlérett, szárított gyümölcsök, de olyan sűrűségben, hogy elzsibbad a tőle a nyelv. És olyan intenzív, hogy szinte éneke.
Dark brown with off-white head.  Taste is banana, caramel, and toffee, maybe a little butterscotch.  Drinks easier than its abv.

Tömény, koncentrált Aventinus ízében és illatában is. Azt pedig egyszerűen nem lehet nem szeretni! Lehengerlő egy sör! Felesleges róla írogatni, csak szimplán ki kell egyszer mindenkinek próbálni, ilyen egyszerű...

Took a while to find this, unrightfully so I might add. Pours a rich dark brown color with a large foamy yet pocked off white head. Nose is green apples, peanut butter, malt of meal, old man cologne, raisins, and brandy. Nice thicker mouthfeel and the taste is exactly the same as the nose. Boozy beer but very good.

330ml bottle from Alko
2009 vintage, bottle no 35692, bbe 23.7.14 - Heavy, complex taste with a lot of banana. Still needs a bit more aging though, alcohol tastes a bit too much, especially when it warms

500ml Bottle. Cloudy deep brown with nice off white head, retained well with nice lace. Banana, cloves/phenolic yeast and a grassy hop note with a nice light grain aroma. Complex, medium body with medium-high carbonation lots of  banana, cloves and a touch of caramel and burnt toffee on the sweet finish. Very flavoursome.

Pours murky dark brown with a decet beige head. Sweet malts, wheat, boozy dark, fruits, licorice, raisins, full body. Taste is sweet, alcohol can barely be perceived. Distinctive Schneider yeast strain. Another masterpiece from this house.

0.33 l bottle from Sörspecialista, Bp.
Hazy mahogany pour with an off-white coloured, stabile, whipped creamy head and fizzy carbo.
Intensive smell of alcohol-dipped/fermented dried fruits.
Tongue numbing start escorted by a thick, sticky and biteble mouthfeel (in spite of that its relative easy to sip).
Complex, strong aroma of alcohol, caramell, cereals, chocolate, citrus and cloves. The powerful flavours of fermented, dried fruits (cherry, forestal fruits, banana), the tart, warming up finish brings alcohol, citrus and spice along, which remains in a tart-fruity aftertaste.
Heavy as f**k, enjoyed it well!
poured dark red. sweet aroma. alcohol well hidden by the sweet taste. finish of pear? maybe. mouthfeel was very oily.not a fan of the style, but it wasnt bad

Sörspecialista, Budapest.
Érdekes, sötétbarna, súlyosan és homályosan hömpölygő ital, olyan mintha valami rejtélyes csodagyógyszer lenne. Sárgásfehér habja vékony, krémes ami gyorsan és minden nyom nélkül tűnik el. A pohárba szagolva olyan illatok törnek fel, mintha egy jóféle gyümölcscefrébe szagolnánk bele, ami éppen csak elkezdett erjedni, de már érezhető, hogy ebből valami nagyon jó és különleges lesz. Az illat tartalmaz még muskotályos szőlőmustot, karamellt, melaszt és egy kis fakérget. Belekóstolva visszaköszönnek az ízben is ezek az aromák, de hagyjuk csak egy kicsit melegedni! Ahogy emelkedik a hőmérséklete, úgy nyílik ki egyre jobban és lesz egyre gyümölcsösebb, gazdagabb. Megjelennek a fűszerek, csokoládé, túlérett banán, füge, datolya, selyemcukor, gyógynövények. Sűrű, nehéz és olajos teste van, tele van apró buborékokkal. A nagyon magas alkohol tartalom szépen elvan rejtve benne, lassan zsibbaszt és melenget. Utóíze gyógyfüves, fűszeres, keserédes, kissé fanyar és nagyon hosszan kitart. Kint szakad a hó, vadul fúj a szél, én bent ülök a szobában, Fourplayt hallgatok és kortyolgatom ezt a fantasztikus sört. Csak nyugodt körülmények között, kellő odafigyeléssel szabad inni ezt a csodát, minden egyes kortya élmény!
Pours a deep dark ruby, sweet and malty, at 12% its quite drinkable. Very nice and probably the benchmark for a rarer style.

0,33 l bottle, bought at the brewery, Kelheim.
Deep rubybrown, murky, untransparent beer with a superb foamy-creamy white head. Concentrated, thick weizen character in the aroma with fruits like fig, mango, banana and grape, huge ammount of spicies like clove, cinnamon. The taste....This is a bomb at the first slip.Powerful fruity and brutal flavor of overriped banana and figs again, raisins and grape. But after a milisecond comes throught a nice taste of chocolate, some tart cherries. Tart fruity aftertaste. Really good one;-)
Bottle. Hazy dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is banana, wheat, clove and spicy vanilla. Flavour is sweet fruity and malty with banana and some wheatbread.

Part of the Great Munich Beer Raid. 330 ml bottle in Germany. Dark amber in appearence with a fast dissapating head. The smell is sharp and sweet.... makes my mouth water... perhaps a bit off... The flavor is darkly suggary, something odd i cant identify... apples perhaps and a bit of cinnamon. Cloves. very alcoholic. Fantastic stuff!!

Nose is of damp fermenting fruit. A surprisingly carbonated beer with a head that disappears quickly and leaves no lace to speak of. Deep dark red, almost purple like the label. Taste is bombastic and sharp at first with the over-powering fruit-like sensation. Notes of bananas that have started to go brown combined with a sweet malty background and almost sour bread on the finish. Alcohol is boozy and warming.

A: Pours a dark brown with a small amount of light penetration. Very thin head and not really any lacing.

S: Dark fruits, sweet malt, and some definite alcohol, which is to be expected.

T: Fairly intense. Loads of sweet malt and alcohol with a good dosing of dark fruits and cherries in the background.

M: Medium body with a nice heat to it.

D: Considering what this is, it ends up being a very nice sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2010

Bottle.  Pour is cloudy deep reddish-purple with a medium lasting tan head.  Aroma fills up the room.  Huge fruity notes with hints of alcohol, light spice, light malt, and a faint red grape note.  Really a very big aroma.  Flavor is sooo smooth.  Lots of dried fruit with notes of yeast and wheat-like malt. Also a hint of vanilla and a creamy mouth-coating finish.  Almost no alcohol detectable even as it warms. This is really a very rich and big beer with an impressive drinkability.  Wow, really great stuff.  I have seen it so many times, glad I finally grabbed one.

Bottle shared by a friend. Clear red pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of booze, berries, banana and caramel malt. Flavor starts off with caramel, then turns to a bit of fruit and some light banana before a boozy finish.

11.2 oz bottle from US Liquors. Deep reddish brown colored pour with a foamy white head.  Intense aroma, dark fruits, almost smells more like a wine.  Flavor, also intense and also showcasing the dark fruit flavors.  Definitely tastes "boozy" but not to the point where its hard to drink because of it.  Tangy fruity finish.  Big & intense beer, almost more of cognac or sherry but surprisingly very easy to drink.
Smells like very strong wine. The tastes follows that with strong alcohol and dried fruit. Very thick and creamy. After taste leaves an awful medicine quality.

Hazy and dark mahogany body with a large, creamy, light tan head. The aroma is strong, with figs, plum, banana, toffee, raisin, wheat, and caramel. The alcohol is noticeable, but not as much a I would expect for 12%. The flavor is a different story. While most flavors in the aroma can be tasted, the finish is most certainly hot. Sweet and boozy, this is definitely a sipper. Creamy mouthfeel with light but plentiful carbonation. Pretty nice winter warmer.
Ok,definetely a very full,thick beer but two drawbacks:Too sweet and almost no foam at all.Had a taste of fruits,like berries and plums, and the aroma was pleasant too.Maybe for a colder country...
Big rich malt driven aroma with some banana & clove ester aroma. Very rich sweet mouthfeel, a little cloying fo my tastes. Might be nice with dome blue cheese go balance the sweetness.

Bottle pours dark brown with thin tan head,  Vinous aroma.  Taste dark fruits, malts, vanilla, molasses.  Alcohol quite apparent but not overbearing and is quite pleasant.  Palate fairly thick, carbonated.  Finish with just a touch of roast but not bitter.

Really nice beer.  The alcohol can knock you for  a loop but what a way to go.

Bottle dated 2008. Poured into a goblet, not much head and looks a but like a glass of maple syrup, or perhaps motor oil. Very rich aroma a flavor. Viscous, light fizz. Tastes like a Heath bar with some raisins as well. The alcohol comes through. Not overly sweet, IMO. Good, but I prefer regular Aventinus.

11.2 oz bottle. Pored into a mug. Dark hazy brown body with a small beige head after an aggressive pour. some floating yeast / sediment.  Smell is very much a weizen smell but more complex with the extra notes of dark fruits and high alcohol. Taste was very much a balance between the wheat bread and raisins with a creamy mouthfeel. I do get that 12% ABV in the taste, the ONLY draw back to the entire brew. Medium carbonation. When it starts to warm up it gets even better. Also got some clove and brown sugar after warming.  Very smooth and well worth whatever you pay for it.

Bottle. Pours a a murky brown/ amber color with a frothy off white/beige head. Aroma is filled with dark fruit, banana, wheat, caramel, spice, alcohol and some vanilla. Flavor is very big and complex with wheat, banana, caramel, dark fruit, brown sugar, spice like clove and alcohol. The body is full, with an almost sticky mouthfeel. Overall a really complex Weizen Eisbock, that is quite alot like the standard Aventinus but bigger!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 My first Eisbock! :-D Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. A deep, clear ruby body resides heavily in my glass, topped with a fine, thin layer of off-white foam. Nose is like a very intensified weissbier: sweet banana tones, cherry, bubblegum, wheat and red apples. Very peculiar. Taste is pretty much exactly the same, with some intensely warming alcohol flavors and a sweet, nougat/cherry-like maltiness hanging around. Strange, but not bad. The closest creation to this I can imagine is a Barley Wine, but the thick, boozy palate of Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock is still pretty far from your average BW. I liked it, but one bottle is clearly enough.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a small head. Very malty, dark, dried fruits, sweet, and lots of alcohol in the flavour. Really good, but Id like to have a few more bottles to try after some time in the cellar.

Bottle.  Pours a murky purpleish brown with loads of sediment with a khaki head.  Aroma consisting of grapes, figs, plums.  Pretty much dark fruits in general.  This beer has a big body.  Sweet fruits, spices, bready yeast, gum that has lost its flavor, and booze is present leading into a long finish.  Quite an interesting beer.  I dig.

From a bottle.  Pour is murky brown with a small khaki head.  Some sediment is present in my glass.  Big dark fruit aroma with a little bit of spicey yeast in the background.  Flavor is nicely spiced with clove and nutmeg.  Dark fruit notes present, with a lingering raisin flavor through the long lasting finish on this beer.  All blend together very nicely, with the alcohol masked nicely.  Quite delicious!
33 cl bottle. Pours cloudy brown colored pour with thin off white head. Roasted malts, slight fruity aroma. Taste is definitely too sweet.

Smells great, looks great and tastes great.  Thats a trifecta if I ever saw one.  Booze soaked dark fruit.  my bottle had some time on it, but it still had some heat.  All in all great beer, but it might be best with some time.  Must find more!

[Bottle] Pours a dark brown color with a large beige colored head. Aroma of weizen yeast, hazelnut and vanilla. The taste is of caramel, molasses, fruity esters, sweet dates/figs and assorted spices. Creamy, rich and full in body. Great balance, with only a faint touch of alcohol in the finish. A tasty brew for sure!

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 21.3.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a thick beige head. Aroma of alcohol, wheat and strong banana. Complex flavour of banana, wheat, alcohol, yeast and caramel. Full bodied with oily mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Very warming finish which makes this a great winterwarmer. Awesome brew, but requires at least one year of aging.
Rich, dark-brown with no head. Rich raisiny, caramel, and madeira aromas. Sweet, malty, with a strong alcoholic bite. Fantastic doppelbock with a twist.

At a tasting: lots and lots of bubblegum, overipe banana, lota of overipe dark fruits, nutty, very yeasty, alcoholic, wheat beer on steroids, not my style at all but interasting and unique.

pours a murkey purple-brown with very little head and no lacing.  Very milky aroma with some grape and plum as well as yeast.  taste is very strong with yeast and some alchohol.  hits the palate like a tawny port.  Really quite excellent.
To sweet for my taste.  Smells like candy and leave a sweet aftertaste.  Has almost no carbonation.  Might have to do a redo on this one...could have been a bad keg.  @3crow.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2013 Thanks kerenmk. 7/3/7/3/12[3.2]

At a tasting, many thanks eyes_wide_shut, dirty brown, with a medium head that disappears quickly, aroma of banana, guava, sweetsop, figs, dates, honey and coriander seeds, flavor is malt with caramel, cinnamon, bubblegum, coriander and mint, extremely zesty, full bodied, great brew  9/3/7/5/15[3.9]

0.33L bottle@ Øl og Mat fest 2010, Oslo. One finger of dense beige head, resting on a cloudy nut brown body. Delicious aroma.  Soft and refined wheaty sweetness, marzipan and toffee, fruit-coctail and dark dried fruits. Supersmooth and silky in the mouth.  Big and complex malt body, caramelly and fruity with notes of  mild spices and warming alcohol. Thick and quite vinous. A great beer, a true world classic.

A pour that piques the interest.  Quite dark brown and very cloudy.  A nice light tan head.  That aroma is mouth watering.  Rich malt.  Name a fruit and it can be found.  Flavor begins with that fruit.  It is not quite as complex as the aroma but is still amazing.  Caramel malt, light spice, alcohol, yeast, cloves.  This is a great beer and one that would be best as an early winter warmer.

At a tasting, many thanks eyes_wide_shut, light murky brown colour, aroma of dates, raisins, dried cherries, spice and some bread in the end, fresh feeling aroma of strawberries, red sour cherries, candy, lavender and a touch of anchovy, long strong but mellow sourness and a touch of alcohol in the back. Excellent and quite delicate for its weight.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2010 Been after this for a while and never seen it anywhere- including Munich, and where does it turn up? Thats right- Coventry. Coventry is awash with Schneider Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock right now. Well, the posh bit around the Earlsdon Rd, anyway. Just dont buy it from the place that used to be Threshers, its a quid cheaper down the road at Alexander Wines- big money on my beer budget. Pours muddily opaque; bitty like black filter coffee with a deep, persisting cappuccino head. Aroma plummy and spiced like Belgium with pronounced clove, mushy banana, Swedish biscuit and bubblegum notes- all that, and then some; loafy malts like rye bread dunked in beef gravy, a waft of acetone once the heads gone. Immediate buzz and glow, huge Belgian-style mouldering apple peel spiciness, thick swirling clods of clovey yeast, Marmite liqueur, banana confectionary. Slides down easy, but the heat lets you know its there. More than anything this reminds me of a huge, dangerous Belgian that smiles benignly but just might take your head off at any moment (De Dolle?), swimming with chunks of...well, who knows what?- a magical feat of brewing considering its just water, hops,malt, yeast.....and magic. A one-off, well worth the wait.

Aventinus
Eisbock
Pours murky brown with brown edges and a medium brown head. Very brown. Aroma is lovely and boozy with raisins, other assorted dark fruits and a nice Germanic spice note.
Flavor is a big bag of wow.  Dark fruits abound, booze spices. Slightly tart on the finish with some caramelly sweetness to balance it out. I like sweet alcoholic beers and this delivers. Good shit! Wish it wasnt $5.00 a 12oz. bottle, but oh well

Shared bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours unclear dark amber with a good sized frothy tanned head. Big sweet malty aroma, candy sugars,dark caramel and some spices. Taste knocks you in your sweet tooth, powerful malty sweetness and alcohol mixture. Not a session beer, but easy drinkable!

An explosion of aroma!!!  Man a lot going on here, I love it. Head disappears quickly but was nice while it lasted.  Medium mouthfeel that is well carbonated.  Taste is strong with a nice alcohol kick.  Dark fruits are in abundance.  Very strong alcohol kick (almost burning).  This beer is one to be careful with I can tell.  I loved it.  Highly recommended.

Rating #150. 50 cL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours hazy mahogany with a tall tan head. The head slowly decreases to a thin cover but leaves a good amount of lace. On the nose, there are aromas of yeast, pepper, clove, apple, plum, alcohol, herbs and grass. The flavour is moderately-intensely sweet throughout with a significant alcoholic component. This is balanced with moderately bitter herbal hops. The finish is long and alcoholic, with some hop bitterness. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and somewhat vigorous carbonation. Overall, this is a nice malty brew with a high dose of alcohol. The malts are relatively complex and it is well assembled overall. The alcohol is a bit too prominent for my taste, but it would be a fine choice as a winter warmer. 2010-08-25

11.2 oz.- Stupid foreigner metric system- Pours brownish black with a thin yet nice white head, this beer wasnt enough to fill my snifter up three quarters the way full. The aroma is raisins or plums, figs (ok maybe a fig newton)  and sweet caramel malt. The flavor is wheaty, fruity, creamy, somewhat sour or tangy, alcoholic is dominant, but it is delicious. Towards the half-way point the beer starts to feel too sweet and alcoholic, definitely a desert brew.

Bottle - Pours deep, murky brown with rosy tints and a nice, foamy light brown head. Really bready, with some light coriander and clove on the nose. A bit of chocolate, and a decent amount of heat--not sharp, but definitely hot. Taste is sweet and bready, with a blast of raisin, plum, and cherry that comes in through the middle. Finishes with more bread and a bit of warmth. Surprisingly drinkable for 12%, and really smooth. Its just on the edge of cloying, but the heat and breadiness keeps it from going too far. I expected a lot from this beer, and it totally lived up to my expectations.

Bottle: Like Aventinus, Pours a dark Ruby Red, with a white fluffy head. Distinctive Yeast Spice Clove Banana smell, with flavors of the like as well as caramel and sugars. I suppose id have to do a blind test to decide whether I like the Eisbock more or less than the standard. I have to say though, that in spite of the heavier alcohol note here, I. Love. this beer.

Bottle. Pour is unclear and brown with minimal head. Aroma is malt and cinnamon and spice. Taste is brunt malt a brown sugar which finishes with spice (cinnamon). Palate has a sticky feel and finishes gritty and dry. Solid beer, drink one!
Bottle from Cavie.  Cloudy brown pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is raisins, alcohol, and cinnamon.  Taste is very sweet up front, fruit, plum, spice, and a little alcohol.

Pours from the bottle a coffee brown with a thick tan head that dissipates quickly. Lots of sediment in the bottle and in the glass. The aroma is of coffee, chocolate and alcohol. The mouthfeel is creamy, syrupy and smooth.  The taste is balanced: subtle sweetness balanced by a pleasant alcohol burn. The finish is much like that of a carbomb and dare I saw, Kahlua. Wow...I was buzzed off of one of these with dinner. A damn good beer.

Bottle. Pours an unclear and dark copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and alcohol. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional bread. The palate is sweetness with some alcoholburn. Overall a beer below average with a good deal of alcohol.
16.9 ounce bottle at Biergarten Haus in DC.  Caramel color.  Aroma of caramel.  Taste of sweet caramel.  Thats about it.
Colours is  unclear copper with a large creamy top. Aroma is banana malt, alcohol and fruit. Flavour malty, fruity, and alcohol.

Pours a dark brown with classic wheat look and a huge bubbly head. Smell is fruity wine, the red berries, cherries etc but not as big as expected from such a strong beer. Bitter taste but alcohol malt sweetness, lots of fruity goodness, like regular aventinus but propelled a whole league forward. Amazing.

Bottle courtesy of Sprinkle. Pours a murky reddish brown with a cream colored head. Aroma is of dry raisins, sweet earth and clay. Taste is dark malts, heavy cherries and slight wood. Finishes tasty and not unpleasant.

Bottle. pours a dark brown color.  A: smells a little farmhouse like, bubble gum, and booze.  T:sweet, explosion of flavors, good carb, caramel, licorice, berries, lil bite of hops, sweet at the end, dry finish.
sour veggies, bitter hops and a little alcohol on the nose, medium-heavy, quite broad body with good carbs, taste is syrup, walnut, late sweet bitterness and wood.

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle.  This is one of the styles of beer left to try on this list, otherwise I wouldnt have sought this one out.  This one kind of kicks you in the face with fruit, but not so much alcohol.  Aroma is a very strong mixture of dark fruits and malt, not really like a Belgian dark but similar in style to that.  Appearance is a very dark brown with a creamy head.  When I poured towards the end there was a ton of yeast sediment, so caution to those who are trying this for the first time.  Taste is very rich, definite dark fruits and after a couple of sips you can really taste that alcohol.  This is much more potent than I thought it was going to be.  Its pretty good, not something Id usually drink but its good.
Pours cloudy copper with a large beige head. Aroma is breaddy malt, alcohol and fruity notes. Flavour malty and fruity, notes of alcohol.

Poured a very dark brown with a small off-white head.  Great aroma of fruit, yeast, wheat, and caramel.  Big fruity wheat taste with hints of raisins and plums.  Sweet and full bodied.  Some alcohol noticeable at first and slightly too much carbonation.  Finish is smooth and full of wheat flavor.  A great beer, but could have hidden the alcohol a little better.
In bottle; stong alcohol aroma. Very very strong beer ... not for the beginner. Notes of wheat.

Bottle, thanks bierkoning! Pours dark, deep brown with red highlights. Aroma was glorious, of caramel, dark fruits, prunes, and something with a juicy, berrylike feel to it, like blackcurrant suryp or wine gum, very fruity. Its also a littly spicy, but I couldnt identify these aromas too well, as my nose was a bit runny. Very sweet on the tongue, this is a sipper for sure. A pleasant alcohol warmth makes it drink like a liqueur, but the surprisingly sparkly carbonation makes it deceivingly drinkable as well. I would actually have liked it creamier and a bit less carbonated. I did really enjoy this a lot though, my girlfriend loved it and I suspect my mother would have as well.
12 oz bottle:  A drinkable glue like substance that has some varnish tone as well.  Finish of wasp killer in a can.  Whew....Hoping it was a bad bottle.
I remember this as being delicious and strong. Kind of syrupy and the wheat is subdued.

Pours a hazy brown with negligible head. Malt dominates as one would expect; toffee, dates, banana, alcohol and spice notes. Very thick and almost saccharine sweet on the tongue, becoming more complex as it warms. Warming finish from the alcohol.

A world-class beer like the original Aventinus, but a little off-balance in my opinion and I prefer the original. This would go down a treat as a digestif.
