alcohol, brown, hazy, sparkling, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel, lively, long finish,
like a strong belgian ale on the taste buds, with a overtly sweet finish and a mild alcohol burn. very complex indeed.

A dark Coca-Cola brown pour with an off-white head that cant wait to disappear.  But for a high ABV thats no surprise.  What is a surprise is to find sediment, as I was sure that the freezing process extracted yeast along with the water - and Ive found no trace of any in this beer before.  Aroma is of roasted malts, raisins, plums and black pepper.  Of course the malt profile is hefty and even on the nose the syrupy sweetness is obvious, but there are some more interesting smells in here too, such as caramelized onions and cloves.  Huge brown sugar and alcohol on the taste, then onto cherries and cognac.  Very spicy.  Mouth feel is thick and wonderful.  It finishes with a lingering sweetness.  This eisbock is best drunk from cold then allowed to warm over the course of an hour or so.  Its big and boozy and really very pleasing.
pour a pretty reddish brown hue smell is of dark fruit and port. very unique flavor some alcohol burn but not harsh very very sweet. finish is smooth

Rating #371, bottle from Fish and Beer  

A muddy greyish brown beer with yeast fragments and a dense white head.
The aroma is berries, mainly redcurrant, and a bunch of hay. Flavor is also hayish and loaded with berries, but the strength of the beer makes it difficult to distinguish the different berry-flavors. Of course there is an obvious amount of alcohol in the flavor, too. The finish is alcohol and hay, followed by warming alcohol. Creamy, thick beer.

A weizen-eisbock.... quite interesting mix. A big 12% ABV. as well. Last one of the night then. Wow ! What a crazy big-ass head. Off-white, huge, long lasting, huge, decent lacing, huge and still there after several minutes. I guess I could say, creamy, foamy and huge. Darker coloured, on the Indian red, brown and beige side with yeast sediments on the bottom and cloudy. Very pleasant aroma of a witbier and weizen. Spicy, white beer yeast and then, the alcohol comes out to play. The taste though, is on the bock side of things. Dark fruits (apples, plum, raisins), nuts and the alcohol is present, but does not burn. Again, interesting mix and quite smooth (but gets the job done - shitfaced).

Wow!!! What a pleasant surprise. Very complex aroma. Strong notes of Banana, Some toffee/caramel . Large quickly disappearing head. Brown caramel hazy color. Taste is that of spice with a very good easy finish. I would never guess that this is a 12% beer. Excellent!!

At first pass the beer had a fruity aroma.  If I closed my eyes I could imagine it as red wine.  The flavor is complex , but there was almost no head to speak of.  It definitely needs to be warmed slightly before enjoying.

Bouteille de 500 ml. Arômes de levure de weizen (un peu de banane, mais surtout du clou de girofle). Belle présence de fruits mûrs et de chocolat. Robe brune et opaque, légère mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, la levure est bien présente et donne un côté épicé très intéressant à la bière. On retrouve également une bonne dose de malt (chocolat, caramel brûlé, fruits confits). Finale sucrée et alcoolisée. Une bonne bière dessert.

Bottle/33cl - Pours a dark brown in color with a small off white head that settled to a thin covering over the beer.  Aroma is malty sweet with plenty of dark fruits and some spiciness.  Flavor is also quite sweet, intense, with dark fruits and a light peppery spice.  Finish is sweet and lingering.  Alcohol is apparent and creates a nice warming feeling as it goes down.  My first eisbock... and a good one.

33cl bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown colour with a huge off-white head. Lots of floaters. Aroma is sweet malt, cherries, cloves and bananas. Alcoholic notes too. Taste is sweet, warm, fruity (cherries and prunes), with little spiciness. Quite thick bodied. Interesting beer, A strange mix of hefeweizen and barelywine.

A strong beer that looks like a barleywine and tastes like a barleywine mixed with wheat. Not to be repetitive, but this beer is a lot like a good barleywine. Its a bit sticky and a bit heavy on the alcohol, but the flavor and smell are excellent. Its sweet, spicy, malty and full of barley and wheat. Theres a lot of fruitiness, mostly raisin. The full, rich flavors and smooth feel hide the alcohol as well as can be asked at 12% abv. I love Aventinus, and this beer is a bit like a barleywine version of it. That might be hard to imagine, but its a great, big, strong beer that you can sip like a fine port.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share! 2009 vintage. Pours a dark caramel colour with a small off white head. The nose is quite intense. Pepper, apple, soft fruit, plums, sugar, smoke, vanilla and a little alcohol on the nose. The flavor is as intense as the nose. Smoke, apples, vanilla, pears, cream, pepper, and plums. Really nice.

Bottle.  Pour was the same as the regular version (hazy/dark brown) with significantly less carbonation and a boozy aroma of brown sugar and plums.  Flavor is also very similar to regular version, except boozier.  Very good, but Id rather drink a few of the regular bottles, than the boozed up version in front of me now

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 additional notes from drinking 12 oz bottle from 2008: grape aroma and flavors are accentuated, close to grape soda. Oxidative notes of dusty flour are welcome.  Off-white 1/4" head of tight bubbles fades to halo, and sticks to sides of glass. Alcohol notes are quite present in finish, but clean and balancing for non-cloying but nearly maple sweet palate.
from bottle:malt alcohol and dark fruit aromas, plum/prune/grape flavors in medium body with slight tautness from alcohol. Spiciness due to wheat in grainbill and/or yeast-derived.

Murky dark brown with a beige head that quickly fades to a coat. Aroma of wheat and dried dark fruits. Taste is powerfully sweet with overt alcohol. Theres treacle, plums, figs and raisins. Pretty spicy too, with cloves, cardamon and black pepper. Only a little syrupy. More of a dark vermouth than port character.  Completely confounded my expectations: I thought Id love this if the bananas of Aventinus didnt come through (and they didnt). The malt complexity is good and its spicier than I guessed, but Im still not quite sold. Too boozy for the depth of flavours, I suppose.

on tap at biergarden in portsmouth. pours a dark, hazy, reddish-amber with a thick, creamy, light beige head leaving nice lacing. aroma is great with big notes of caramal, cooked banana, belgian spice, sweetbread, cinnamon, and yeast with a touch of honey. flavor is bold and delicious with loads of toffee, burnt caramel, and dark fruits with notes of light banana, nutmeg, and cedar with a warming, sweet, smokey finish. palate is full bodied with solid carbonation and very easy drinking for 12%. complimented the authentic german sausages and red cabbage beautifully. so well, i had 3 glasses.
Nice caramel brown haze to it. With its fruity scent and sweet taste. This beer is delightfully good.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 11.2 oz. bottle, pours dark brown with a reddish tint and a sizable beige head. Aroma of strong caramel malts, toffee, and dark fruits. Flavour brings out potent notes of banana, clove, toffee and a slight alcohol tingle. Very full-bodied, much more so than the regular Aventinus. Extremely well-balanced - the freeze distillation done wonderfully.

11.2 oz bottle to shaker.  Pours very dark amber with off white head that is gone quick, and has no lacing.  Malt and fruits and some coffee and alcohol.  Great body and mouth feel.  Taste is malt and sweet and alcohol. I really like bocks, and this is one hell of a bock and with a hellacious kick too.

Pours a dark, hazy mahogany color, creating a big head that quickly disappears to leave a tiny foam ring and no lacing whatsoever. Very boozy on the nose, but also some heavy malts and dark fruits. In the mouth, juicy flavors of bananas and cloves are showing up as well. Lots of sweetness but the body is big enough to handle it.
A bit one-dimensional for my taste. Although tasty, the intense malt is a bit overwhelming.

Bottle. Thanks to fata2683. My very last style tick: Eisbock! Yes! Pours mildly hazy, red/brown, with a medium off-white head. Spotty/poor lacing. Nose is amazing, like the Aventinus Weizenbock turned up to 11! Fruit, sarsaparilla, jerky, smoke, banana, yeast, vanilla. Flavors of smoke, booze, candy, fruit, vanilla, cola, red licorice. Other than the booziness, this beer rocks!

Pours deep amber. Aroma is amazing it is strong flavour of all the fruit and malt of aventinus with a very srtong smokey aroma. Flavour is everything that I love about nbeer fruity, malty nutty, black pepper and spices. yeasty lots of nutty charcater. smokey like fresh bacon. this is amazing!!!!!!. I could drink it every day. It is everything about aventinus that I like plus smoke. I love it!!!!!.

11.2oz bottle from City Beer 
Appearance: Hazy dirty brown with a small frothy off-white head with very little lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Dark fruits, sweet malts and hot alcohols 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel. Sweet malts, raisins, grainy and hot alcohols 
This would taste good on a cold night.

Medium beige head. Hazy opaque black body goes dark brown at edges. Intense banana aroma with herbal mealy roasty notes. Sweet-dryish alcoholic banana and wheat taste with peppery hoppy notes. Light body. Hot, spicy mouthfeel. Dry peppery alcoholic banana aftertaste with mealy licorice notes. Technically impressive, but the banana and alcohol combination is not ideal. One for the cellar, methinks. (0.33l bottle, Systembolaget, Stockholm.)

Bottle. Brown pour with some tan head. Very rich, full of sweet fruity esters, and malty caramel etc, aromas. Flavor is strong, which is expected, moderate warming but not overpowering for 12, dark fruits, and caramel.
Bottle.  Brownish beer with a rich and roasted aroma.  The flavour is rich, malty and roasted.  Overall a nice rich beer that is mildly bitter.

33 cl bottle. Murky brown color with tan head. Aroma is banana, alcohol, wheat and raisin the same as the flavour. The wheat bitterness balances out the sweetness in a good way. Thick mouthfeel. The alcohol is noticable, this is beer-booze in good way. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a deep copper/brown with a good off-white head.  Aromas of fruits, wheat and spices.  Taste is very fruity masking some of the wheat bitterness, this is mixed with added spices but ends with the wheat bitterness coming through.  Noted some alcohol sharpness, but still a very nice brew.
Definitely loses the subtle flavors of the Aventinus, but its satisfying nonetheless. Its like Aventinus syrup.

Deep brown, red glow, small tanned head.
Aroma of caramel, faint fruit, mostly citrus and banana.
Flavour is very sweet of banana and caramel with sidenotes of spices and citrus. Expected more of this, too sweet overall.

Bottle, thanks for sharing, dEnk! Pours a deep amber to ruby red with a very thin white head. Aroma of spicy sugary malts with some licorice and alcohol. Flavor is heavily sweet malts with a warming alcohol backbone and slightly bitter in the finish. Mostly sweet though. Syrupy texture and medium carbonation. Nice.

Bottle:Pours muddy brown with a thick head. Aroma is quite sweet and has notes of banana, yeast, toffee and marshmallows. Thick mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet and has notes of caramel, toffee, yeast and a little bit of liquorice. Warming alcohol finish.

I fucking bum the normal Aventinus so I was well happy when I saw this. Must admit, was maybe expecting a little more. I feel harsh saying that because I know its unfair as it would have had to have been a top ten beer to live up to my expectations. Dark muddy brown with a short lived off white head. Aroma is banana, wheat. Flavour is some nice banana and lemon, raisin, alcohol. Really enjoyed it, just mildly gutted it wasnt a top ten beer for me. Still very good.

Bottle.  Hazy brown with an off-white head.  Aromas are raisins and yeast with plummy fruitiness.  Banana with some floral notes.  Woody with spices.  Flavours are sweet raisins and caramel with some lemon sherbet.  Gritty grain with ripe pear and some hints of chocolate.  Obvious alcohol on the finish.  Decent.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 Bottle 33cl in Gemany. A dark amber beer with low carbonation. A surprizing beer wich is quite a liqueur, sweet and complex. Aroma of fruits and spicies, notes of honey. Some vinous small can be detected as well as vanilly. The weizen taste is there but not much the beer is very drinkable, the hops characters are low.
Very very intresting
A huge beer- but a huge style. Smell of currant, cherry, apricot and booze. Taste is dark fruits and sweet malts- Alcohol is obvious but compliments the beer..

Bottle.

Pours realy dark brown with a tan head.

Compelx beer with aroma and tast of dark fruits, herbs (like jägermeister), cola and belgian like yeast.

Dark brown, small head, Very strong malty aroma. Strong in taste, lots of alcohol. Bitter finish, fizzling in mouth and warming alcohol. Everer sip is a nice one, with every sip you taste more and other ingredients. Alcohol is overwhelming, maybe a little bit too much, but nice to drink.

WHOA!  I dont know much about an eisbock, this was intense.  To me this was most closely related to a belgian quad of the styles I know.  Incredible carmel flavor in the nose and all through the body.  You have to sip this like a liquor, its that strong a flavor and you can really taste the alcohol in this.  still, its pretty sweet.

This ranks as one of the best beers I have ever had.  I even had my wife try it, and although she hates beer (sniff, sniff), she thought this had a great taste.  She was probably won over by the sweetness of the caramel that came through in the taste.  Dont worry as it doesnt overpower the beer because there is so much going on her.  II think you will be greatly satisfied.

33cL Bottle. Subtle, salty malt-wheat aroma, backed with a sweet touch of almond, banana, and warm bread. Pours a slightly hazed dark amber and sienna with an off-white head. Flavors cover the breadth of banana, hazlenut, pale chocolate, sweet wines, and chewy grains. The alcohol is nice and snappy, with good warm, legs, and brandy-like complexity. Its maybe not as dense as some Eisbocks Ive sunk my teeth into, but the flavors are delightful, the profile is complex and expressive, and overall its delicious.

Thick copper pour with very little head. Had a very nice color, dark and deep, very pretty color.  The aroma is strong, had powerful fruit tones which i thought were supported well by the malt.  Although there seemed to be some fusel alcohol flavors in the beer which really gave the beer an overly alcoholic taste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a light brown head. Aroma has a strong alcohol note with an undertone of sweet grains. Flavor is similar with a strong sweet grain note as well as a strong alcohol note.

330mL bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a small persistent off-white head.  Complex aroma of banana, clove, feijoa, rockmelon, caramel, yeast, a little toast and alcohol.   Very sweet but not over the top, while the alcohol is perhaps close to it.  On the heavier side of medium bodied, the alcohol is very warming on the back palate and throat.  Soft carbonation with a sweet and warming finish.

Banana and bubblegum on the nose along with some alcohol. Full-on taste bud assault in the mouth. Concentrated flavour reminiscent of conserves. Starts off with banana bonbon getting progressively more sweet (never annoyingly so) to the end. Theres even a bit of citrus in there as well. Odd and interesting combination.

330 ml bottle. Dark brown body with off white foam. Aroma has tart, bubblegum and bananas. Brady malt and little alcohol. Oily, full mouthfeel. Flavour has lots of bananas and tart. Malty bready wheatness is very present. Great winter warmer.
UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Bottle 330 ml. Dark brown and ruby color with white average head.Aroma vanilla and fruits. Taste banana, vanilla, chocolate.Full body, lasting finish. Great beer.

Bottle. 

Dark murky reddish brown with a small head. Small lacings. 

The nose is packed with banana aromas and soft banana candy. Notes of caramel, spices and prominent wheat aromas. 

The  flavor is really sweet, almost cloying. Chewy sugary aromas of soft banana candy and notes of spices. Strong wheat character. The finish is somewhat warming and sweet from the alcohol. 

Full-bodied and chewy texture. 

A special experience, for sure. Damn this beer tastes like sweet banana candy.

Appearance: 4/5
Dark hazy brown liquid with a medium sized dirty white foam.

Smell: 8/10
Strong smell of foam bananas and booze.

Taste: 8/10
Foam banana, fresh bananas and vanilla. Fairly sweet and with a noticeable alcoholic profile.

Mouthfeel: 5/5
Thick body, smooth mouthfeel and alcoholic warmth.

Comment:
Wow! A very thick, intense, complex and high alcoholic wheat beer. I tried a Franzizkaner on the side and it tasted like water in comparison. It had allot of bananas but not only foam bananas, also some fresh bananas.

I usually prefer my wheat beers during hot summer days but this beer feels to strong for that. It might work well with certain cheeses, but I also believe this could work as an aperitif, possible coupled with a dessert. Unfortunately I didnt have any sweets to try it with at the time.

A very interesting beer that I wouldnt mind trying again. Curious on how this will evolve over time I will save a bottle for later.

Big beige/brown head, deep copper/ruby colour
Ar: Spices, wheat, bananas, yeast, malts.
F: Alcohol, yeast, spices, dried fruits, malts, wheat. Well balanced.
M: Smooth, little carbonation.
T: Weizen on steroids.
Clear dark brown color/ tan head. Big dark grape juice, plum, dark bread aromas. medium body. Dark raison, sweet yeasty dark wheat bread flavors. Mild heat to finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Pours dark orange, deep dark red in the glass, Golden head. Thick looking liquid. Strange sweet and complex aroma. Notes of chocolate, syrup, dried fruits, tigerbalsam. Boozy, still sweet, taste.  Red orange, oboy, small smokeiness, raisin and licorice. Some alcohol in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is thick and smooth.

Pours a dark brown color with a mediumsized white head, some lacing. Aroma is powerful with notes of spices, bubblegum, banana, toffee, liqurice and alcohol. Flavour is sweet and very malty with lots of spices, bubblegum, banana, liquorice, toffee and warming alcohol in the finish. Fullbodied, syrupy thick mouthfeel. Very nice!

Pours a dark granite with a healthy off white fizzy head.  Aroma is tinny, with purple fruits  and malt.  Taste is astringent, an alcohol bite but somewhat balanced with caramel and plum or raisins.  Not a bad beer.

Bottle, 2010-03-11, Göteborg
AR. alcohol, popcorn and carmel
AP: dark brown body, nogat colored 3 cm creamy head
F. belgian yeast, vinos as the Primator 21^ consumed 1 h before. aluminium, and clove - the two last ones are not adding anyting rather the opposite. Wife didnt finish her glass! (I helped her so when it reached room temp it is a little bit better!)
From a bottle poured a hazy brown color with a fair amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a light tart finish.
Bottled. Dark brown opaque colour with dissapearing white head. Alcoholic bananic aroma. Taste is strong with banana and maltiness. Full bodied quality eisbock.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Murky brown. Mediumbeige head.
Spicy, sweetish aroma. Vinous in both aroma and flavour.
Sweet and oily palate.
Some licorice.

Bottle from LCBO. Fizzy when pouring, but almost no head resulted from it. The color is an opaque brown, with a tinge of red. It has a wonderful aroma. A very fruity nose, with hints of caramel, yeastiness, and a hint of the alcohol. A thick, yet subtle palate of fruits and caramel. Some of the alcohol is evident in the taste. A bit of the wheat come through also. It also seems to fizz a little in your mouth. Very Nice!

Dark amber with little head. Aroma yeast, fruit. Taste very sweet and fruity from plum, date, alcohol. Body is full, text is thick like port. good carb, sweet finish. Nice to cheese. A couple of these will certainly make you sing. Good.

Bottle.

Hazy dark brown with a tan large head. Wonderful malty wheat beer aroma, banana and spices. Also some dark fruits, raisin and syrup.

Very tasty, tastes like wheat beer, but much more. Quite sweet and with some sour notes. Alcohol, malt, syrup, spices and some chewing gum. Nice mouth feel. Very drinkable, a very good beer.

Bottle (33 cl) from Systembolaget. Well, an upscaled Aventinus, and unfortunatley, the most distinguishing feature is a clear alcohol component. Still very good, but I will stick to the ordinary Aventinus.

This brew pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with very little head.  Aroma is definitely full of fruits.  I can pick out raisins, plum, black cherry, and some green apples.  Theres also wheat and brown sugar in the background.  Taste has a little booze in it and also quite sweet.  Flavors include fruits, brown sugar, and wheat.  Has a sweeter aftertaste.  This is very good stuff.

Almost black, cloudy, with a fine, high, light tan head. Fruity, spicy aroma, with cherry, raisin, fig, banana, chocolate. Sweet, fruity, burning flavor. Acidic, spicy, and a huge alcohol burn. There is quite a sour edge to it, to go with the sweetness. Smooth and silky. Completely different to the regular version--maybe not as good all-around, but still very interesting and a cool sipping drink.

Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Dark opaque brown in colour, with reddish undertones and a decent, off-white head. Aroma of red fruits, dates, bananas and cloves. Flavour had plenty more fruit ans spice, with a touch of bubble gum, leading to a dryish finish. Alcohol was well hidden. Very good.

cloudy dark brown, smooth creamy offwhite head.
strong dark fruity aroma, also some sour wheatish notes.
flavor is wheat, yellow fruits, quite sweet, some hops present, alc can be felt. quite a sweet experience, tastes sort of like if i had mixed a brune with a weissbier. The beer has many taste notes and a complex character, like if it was a belgian beer. It grows on You. Take Yor time.

A: Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. The beer is a dark brown with lots of red tint and a fluffy tan colored foam.

S: This is my first eisbock, so I wasnt quite sure what to expect from the nose. A great fruity aroma, a mild funk, and a fair bit of spice--mostly clove. There is a lot of banana, presumably from the yeast.

T: What an interesting mix of flavors. A lot of clove and nutmeg, a fair amount of banana, raisin, and plum. The funkiness that was present in the nose is not on the palate. There is also a touch of alcohol, but not surprising at 12% ABV.

M: A great full body on this beer. The carbonation is surprisingly high, but I think this is a very good thing.

D: Despite the relatively high alcohol content, the beer is very drinkable. A great mix of flavors and a very enticing aroma. I would gladly drink this one again and seek out some more eisbocks.

Bottled. Pours hazy and deep brown with a large, light brown head. Nose of port and dark fruits. Sweet, complex, caramel flavour with dark fruits and malt. Full bodied. Syrup texture. Some alcohol in the finish. Enjoyable.

Pours a nice brown/amber.  Aroma is floral and nutty with caramel, malt and licorice.  Taste is medium bodied, with caramel, malt, bitter hops, orange, and nuts.  Good, but finish is a bit too alcoholic.
Dark, rich and stong beer.  Has a bit of a winey taste because of the high abv, but the dark wheat style is a good heavy match for the strength.  Unique beer I recomend to anyone who has a chance.
33 cl bottle. Cloudy brown body with tan head. Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel and fruit.

500 mL bottle.  Purchased this by accident thinking it was the normal Aventinus.  Pours a cloudy, slightly syrupy brown.  Aroma is of malt and fruits - banana and strawberry.  A bit of a burnt sugar aroma as well.  Taste is powerful - starts off sweet, then the high alcohol content reaches the nostrils.  Aftertaste is of lingering sweetness.  Body is full, with moderate carbonation and a slightly syrupy texture.  Very nice overall.

Dark brown in appearance, very strong banana on the nose and nothing else. Feels velvety creamy smooth in the mouth, like a banana milkshake. Strong hints of prune with a definite port base, alcohol is well upfront but combines flawlessly with everyhting else. Like a warm blanket in front of the fireplace.

This is my first beer review.

330ml bottle. Cloudy brown colour, beige head. Aroma is twisted: banana with some earth, licorice and flowers. Taste isnt too heavy or creamy, and medium carbonation lightens the taste. Cherries, spices and various fruits. Alcohol leaves creamy toffee-like layer on your mouth for quite a while. Very nicely balanced.

Draft @ de Paas. Nose is dark malted wheat cereal with a touch of banana and raisin. Flavor is the nose, but much more pronounced fruits (figs, prunes and the classic hefe flavors of banana with a touch of herbalness) -a very vinous finish reminiscient of a well-aged zinfandel. Booze is noticeable throughout, though its well integrated with the dark fruits. One tasty beverage.

Bottle. The aroma is very malty, reminds me of fresh bread and milk chocolate, nice smell. The small beige creamy head has a long duration, the body is nearly black. The taste is very malty, some chocolate, the finish is a little bit alcoholic. The body is strong, creamy and with a normal carbonation.

Extremely pungent. Alcohol, cloves, spices, tons of yeast. Brown in colour, huge head, beautiful head sadly dissipates fairly quickly. This is an extremely potent beer, you are hit with alcohol up front. Thick, very very full bodied, very spicy, with a yeasty aftertaste. The alcohol covers up the subtle flavours which make the standard Aventinus great, although it is very nice to have the warmth of 12% alcohol on a cold Canadian winter night. Very smooth, winey, and boozy. A good beer, but not quite as great as Aventinus.

11.2 ounce bottle in snifter.  Dark reddish brown with ring and a little lace.  Rich plummy tangy woody earthy grassy aroma with hint of caramel.  Sweet toasted caramel with mildly tangy dark fruit and earthy woody finish with some warmth and bite.  Fun to try but a little over-the-top and slightly harsh.
0.33l 2008/24221 - Cloudy brown with light tan head that stayed for a while.  Flowery, spring-like nose with some sweet malt notes.  Yeasty bread with hints of booze at end.

Location: 11.2 oz bottle from Norms, 1/26/10 
 2008 Bottle, #16648


Aroma: Lots of dried fruits, some dark malts, caramel, booze, and some sugary sweetness.

Appearance: This one pours a murky, dark brownish-orange color with a minimal (light brown) head.

Flavor: Taste is quite sweet, somewhat complex in flavor, some spice, wheat, and some fruit.

Palate: This one has a pretty full body, the booze are there, particularly in the finish.

Overall Impression: 
This beer is pretty interesting.  Certainly a sipper.  The booze is certainly present, and you can feel it, but I dont think it takes away from the beer at all.  There is a lot of stuff going on with this beer, quite complex.  I like it, but it isnt something I would want to drink all the time.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into snifter. Pours a deep, translucent brown color with a fluffy tan head. The aroma is sweet and spicy; malts, bananas, dried fruit, caramel, and clove. The bananas, cloves, and caramel carry over into the taste. Very complex. Lively carbonation and a dry, boozy finish. Warms you from the inside. Enjoyable.

12 oz bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar. Appearance is deep rich ruby brown. Very clear body even with the large chunk of yeast in the bottle. Nice small  off white head. The aromas are full of proofing yeast, wheat, some dried fruit touches. Wow crazy flavors here. Sweet malty base with  fruit accents  subtle fruit accents like banana and grape, some peppercorns, clove. Not sure what I was expecting but this is super smooth and creamy. The alcohol is well hidden. It only comes through with a warm aftertaste in the mouth. Excellent brew.

Draft from a wooden gravity cask @ redlight redlight. Pours a hazy amber brown with a thick lasting creamy head. Aroma of thick rich malt, rich dark fruits like prunes and plums, wheat and a touch of booze. In flavor this is like Aventinus cubed. Just super rich, sweet, some booze, but nice with dark fruits all around. Surprisingly light in the mouth with a nice alcohol dryness.

A clear brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma is malty sweet, with fruits, like bananas and raisins. There is wheat. The taste of sweet fruits like raisins with bananas, malts and wheat. In the back some alcohol. the aftertaste is sweet with some bitter and burny.

Wood cask at Redlight Redlight. Pours translucent brown with small tan head. Aroma is fantastic, very complex, sweet, fruit, some alc. Taste is pretty much the same, very full mouthfeel, lots of dark fruit, slightly bready, only a bit of alcohol burn, which genuinely surprised me giving the abv but, then again, theres so much else going on. So glad I got to try this.

Aroma of chocolate, roasted caramel and almonds. Appearance is cola-like with carbonated tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with an emphasis on caramel malts. Palate is bubbly and sticks to the tongue. My favorite German beer.

Dark brown amber pour unfiltered lots of sediment ....light off white head smells of bread and dark fruits .... taste of bread, wheat, little alcohol, sweet malts, dark fruits..... its like bitter and tart at the same time .... a very well balanced beer that hides the abv well .... a really awesome style very complex

Wooden gravity cask at redlight redlight.  Pours a cloudy brown amber with a generous beige head.  The nose is wonderfully complex.  Strong earthiness alongside some dark fruits; plums, figs, pickled apples, etc.  Also some dough and just a hint of the boozy high alcohol.  The flavor is something else to behold.  Pungent but not too sharp.  Bitter/sweet with a very subtle tartness in the middle.  Very delicious.  just an utterly fantastic beer.

I actually wasnt that big a fan of regular Aventinus, but this was something else. Delicious complex aroma and smell while remaining both harmonious and strong. Excellent beer, and one of my favourites, now. Truly outstanding.

Dark brown and sleightly murky with a minimal bubling brown head. The aroma holds all the goodies of a regular aventinus. Vinouse, dates and figs. Flavor is very sweet which is necessary because of the high abv, still the alchohol is abit too much for thi beer i think. Still very very delicios
Pours a dark brown with tan head. Smells fruity with a taste of banana and and aftertaste of spice.  Tastes good.  Very drinkable. Not my favorite.

( 11.2oz bottle vintage 2009 thanks to mar) Pours ruddy orange-brown with ok lacing and head. Nose of wheat, yeast, mild alcohol, and dark fruit. Taste is banana, spices, milk chocolate, with creamy carbonation. Finishes thick, creamy and no alcohol linger. Delicious syrupy finish on this one.

Color is dark hazelnut brown with a thick tan head. Aroma is caramel, spices, nuts, bubblegum, and maybe a hint of chocolate. Flavor is a delicious balance of sweet and bitter, with the caramel coming through in the finish. Absolutely delicious. Very refreshing. Why havent I tried this before?

08 vintage 11.2 oz bottle pours deep red-brown with a decent amount of off-white head into a snifter.  Aroma of.. a stronger, darker hefe: grassy, clove, spice, banana, apricot, vanilla, sweet malt, booze is definitely detectable.  Starts with banana, vanilla, plumb, finishes with plenty of booze, banana, spice, biscuity malt.  Frothy mouthfeel with low carbonation and full bodied.  Warms exceptionally well.  Bit cidery, caramel in the finish comes out toward the end.  Interesting and very tasty.

Hazy, dark brown color; sweet, warm aroma of yeast, banana, dark fruits like plum and raisins; medium to full body, quite high carbonation; flavor is sweet, dark fruits, banana, touch of alcohol; warming finish.

Very special beer. Complicated strong aroma of malts, fruits, caramel, raisins. Taste is sweet and strong with fruits (orange,banana,apple), malts, sugar and caramel and bites of alcohol. Nice choice especially for cold winter nights.

33cl bottle, Alko. 2009/36950. Pours cloudy, brown color with a thick tan head. Aroma is strongly of raisin and malt. Flavor is quite sweet, nice taste of raisins and alcohol. Full bodied, very warming on a cold day.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown with moderate tan head.  Nose of banana, dark fruit, brown sugar and spice.  Flavour is banana, caramel, some dark fruit and a mild spiciness.  Syrupy texture.  Masks the 12% well.  Nice beer.

bottle - pours dark brown with a light tan head. The nose is full of bubblegum, orange peel and spice, I detected the slightest trace of rubber but it did nothing to detract from the aroma. The taste was an explosion of baked bananas, caramel and orange. There was a slight hint of alcohol but considering the ABV was quite muffled, I also detected a slight bit of Borkum Riff tabacco as the beer warmed........Bravo-Bravo

This is an amazing and complex beer which almost has a Smokey flavor to it. A nice reddish brown tint with an off white head this beer is thick on the pallet true to Eisbock tradition. The alcohol comes across more than some others in the style but all and all this is a very enjoyable beer!

Although pleasantly complex, too much alcohol comes through to make this enjoyable for me but after consumption of one bottle I was feeling quite giddy. Upwards character of cloves and bananas, just a little too much punch.
50 cl bottle, Mulmur, ON, Canada. Deep hazy brown colour, strong banana aroma. Sweet, smooth and very mellow for a 12% beer, bubblegum and faint caramel on the finish.
Bottle. Poured dark black with far too much head.  Very over carbonated.  Aroma of caramel malt and banana. Banana caramel and wheat in the flavour with a hop tinge.  Malty sweet finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 Pours hazy dark brown with medium brownish head. Aroma is quite wheaty with some banana and plum. Flavor is much of the same, with some alcohol pushing through, but not too much. Superb.

Pours ruby brown with a medium white head that leaves some lacing. Fairly big aroma with lots of booze, dark fruits as well as some wheat beer characteristics. Taste is similar with some yeasty character, more dark fruit and some alcohol. Good flavour as well as nice and complex, just a little too alcoholic for me.

Gravity keg at Swift. Pours a chocolate-brown, incredibly effervescent, with a thin, fluffy beige head. Nose of heavy malts with notes of vanilla and clove. Taste has lots of malt too, and dark fruits also sneak into the picture. Full-bodied and creamy with loads of carbonation. Semi-warming from the ABV, although the alcohol was truly not that present to me. Nice, light malt finish. Strong yet restrained, this was a great beer.

Bottle at Malthouse, via Beerstore.co.nz. Pours murky brown. Dark, thin off white head.
Potent aromas, a banana bomb with warm alcohol. A fair amount of vanilla and cinnamon. 
Intense flavour, banana, roasty malt choc. Alcoholic warmth which provides a bit of biting bitterness. This counters the big sweet bananas.
Not as balanced as the normal Aventinus, but thats why I love it!

A: Pours a very effervescent dark brown color with a huge head. The head settled down nicely though to just over one finger in size. 

S: There is a huge malt smell from this one. I detect hints of banana, clove, and maybe even some vanilla, pretty nice. 

T: Huge alcohol taste here, a little too boozy for my liking. I realize it is 12% ABV and it shows. Behind the alcohol I could taste a molasses like sweetness along with dark fruits like figs and raisins. 

M: Full bodied and carbonated, leaves a slight sting from the alcohol. 

D: Not my cup of tea, one bottle was plenty.

Bottle, 33cl - Hazy brown beer with a small head. Aroma is malty with notes of fruits, plumes and cherries. Flavor is sweet malty with notes of vinous malt, ripe fruits, yeast and some alcohol. Very nice and sophisticated Eisbock.

330ml bottle, no.22205/2009, bought at the splendid shop called Bier Spezialitäten Laden in Karl Marx Allee. Decent, off-white head over a deep, dark brown body. Inviting aroma of brown malt mixed with dark fruits. Rich taste profile with spiced dark fruits, including figs and apricot, and with the adding impacts of dark wheat. Long-lived aftertaste of jam-like tartness. Vinous to the palate. Detectable alcohol, but not annoying. Maybe a bite too much on the sweet side, however, still German brew craft at its best (Agon hotel, room 802, Berlin 22.11.2009).

Pours a deep mahogany-chestnut into the glass, with tons of yeasty "floaties" and an initial 4-finger brown head that reduces to trace bubbles.  The nose is of sugary dark fruits... plums, prunes, raisins, a touch of vinous notes, with a hint of licorice and worn leather.  Flavors contain similar dark fruit esters, with rich sweet (dark) malts, bananas, a touch of clove, an alcohol burn, and a heavier raisin/dried prune finish.  The mouthfeel is syrupy, with a heavy, full body.  The alcohol heat is noted and appreciated for integration into the huge amount of complexities in the flavor palate.  A weizen-bock on steroids, this rich brew is enjoyable best in cold weather, either as an aperitif or nightcap.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 After reading some of the ratings for this beer I am starting to think I may have just had a bad bottle... but as my bottle was $6 and I will not be buying another due to the one I had... here goes: Poured a dark brown color with a red tint, small head that went away in under a minute. Aroma was earthy and sweet... mixed with booze. I thought the strongest flavors in this beer were olives and licorice... which was unique. However, I also thought it was very watery and too sweet... and had no body or depth. I could smell the alcohol but it tasted more like watered down booze. The bottle states this one as 12% alcohol but I cant say I felt a thing.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown.  potent aroma.  Notes of banana, bubblegum, raisin, vanilla, alcohol.  Like a sweet banana laden glass of port.  Enjoyed smelling this over and over again.  alcohol  is a nice compliment and never overpowering.  Definitely a sipper.  Great beer.
11.2 oz bottle.  Pours deep brown in colour, clear, with a modest head.  Big aroma and taste, with a bit of toffee, alcohol sneaks through the flavour.

11.2 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (bottle 2009/11134).  Muddy brown pour with a thick off-white head.  Unassuming aroma of bubblegum and bready yeast.  Sugary sweet flavor of banana, wheat, and sugar.  The sweetness is really intesified over regular Aventinus.  Moderate alcohol warming but nothing of great significance.  Overall a very good beer but I give a slight edge to the regular Aventinus.

From the Bottle at the GBBF, Earls Court 06/08/2009
Big fruity aroma. Some carbonation. Small beige head. Dark coloured and very strong in alcohol with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.

2008 bottle.  Pours a deep cloudy brown with plenty of yeast at the bottom of the bottle.  Head is deep tan to light brown and plenty thick and creamy, died off to a thin skim over the course of a few minutes.  Smell is vaguely clovey with hints of bananas and a strong malty backing.  Also a faint hint of yeast.  In the mouth very thick, very creamy feeling.  Starts out pretty bitter and then gets plenty of spices.  Not as much yeast shows through in the flavour as the amount of yeast that was in the bottle.  Theres lots of dark fruity notes, dates, cherries, and the like. Plenty of alcohol warmth in the finish.  Wonderfully complex, and very thick.  Carbonation is low, but appropriate.  Very nice beer.

BOTTLE NUMBER: 2009/01404

This one pours a darkly shaded, golden brown color. Almost a fingers worth of dark tan colored foam forms the head. It recedes to a thin, spotty, surface covering. The lacing is spotty as well and fairly slick.

Theres no denying that this one has a good amount of booziness to it. At 12.00%abv though, its no real surprise. Its loaded with dark fruits, especially cherries. There is a delicious yeastiness, combined with a good deal of wheat, that smells like pie crust. This is the nose of a maltbomb, as far as the sweetness presence goes.
Somewhat like Id expect a pie made from maraschino cherries and rum to smell like.
This is one of the best smells that I know of, for a malt forward brew. Deliciously enticing.

Everything from the nose is still here. Its now joined by a wonderful gingerbread presence though, which is beautiful. It has a nice level of spiciness. The high abv, while not entirely hidden, is not nearly as noticeable as the nose prepared you for. It has a nice warmth going down, but not the heat that was expected.

Full-bodied, getting close to thick. It has a medium-to-high level of carbonation, which gives it just a touch of roughness that works against the creaminess that it has. Just slightly shy of perfection.

The high abv is hidden well enough and this one tastes very nice, if you dont mind the sweet/maltbomb side of the spectrum. I could drink several of these at one sitting, and I have several times. This is one of my go-to beers.
Its recommended, if youve never had it. It could become your new dessert beer, if nothing else.

11.2oz 2008 bottle.  Pours a dark red/brown with a small off-white head with low retention.  Aroma has intense fruitiness, phenols, banana, caramel, dark fruits, cotton candy.  Flavor shows all the same characteristics as the aroma plus a pronounced sweetness.  Alcohol is relatively well hidden.  This was pretty good.
(Bottle).  dark/caramel color. taste of banana and raisins with whiskey-like alcohol flavor after.  This beer hides its alcohol content very well.  A very nice beer.

Dark brown color with an almost purple hue. Big puffy light brown head that decides to stick around for a bit. Thick and murky. Leaves chunks of Nestle Quik debris on the sides when finished.

The spicy aroma of a very dark weizenbock. A pungent burnt banana. Slight alcohol aroma wafting above.

The taste is strong whiskey alcohol. As it mellows, the weizen/yeasts come out. A very strong weizenbock. Has some of that spicy Belgian flavor.

There is an honest-to-God burn on the way down. Medium-bodied otherwise, but a tad bubbly. A very strong and heavy beer. Dark and full of alcohol.

2005 330ml bottle (2005/09076). Pours very nearly flat, with only a tiny ring of foam along the edges, even after a vigorous pour. A very clean but dark brown color. Aroma is sweet, a bit boozy, with maybe a little clove. On the palate, theres a little small bit of fizziness, definitely not fully carbonated, though. Fairly thick, could use some carbonation to lighten things up. Flavors definitely boozy, with raisins, plums, other fruits beneath. Cant really find any of the banana/clove esters youd expect from a weizenbock - Im sure the age has something to do with that. Definitely a malt bomb by this point, which should be expected after freeze-distilling and 4 years. Probably better fresh or with 1-2 years on it. Also carbonation would be nice. Still, though, nice to try.

330 ml bottle (32188/2009). Hazy reddish brown in colour with abundant tan head. Aroma has banana and sugary, caramel-like sweetnes in it. The flavour also includes some banana as well as some raisin-like component. Alcohol can be easily noticed, too. Above-medium carbonation.

Bottle as part of a tasting at Catskeller.  Pours hazy brown with a big tan head.  Aroma of banana, caramel, clove, and sweet malts.  Flavor is more of the same, well balanced, along with some berry and dried fruits, bread, and alcohol.  The alcohol seemed lighter than 12%.  Medium bodied, with a grainy mouthfeel.  Very good eisbock, which normally isnt one of my favorite styles.

Poured into Snifter. Surprisingly little head despite central pour.  Dark fruity taste builds quite a full bodied beer. Was a little more carbonated than i was expecting, but it turned out that it countered the high alcohol percentage nicely.  Enjoyable for sure. Definitely recommend

Bottle. Dark brown with a stable head. Complex, winous, fruity aroma. Flavours start sweet and fruity, good sour cherries provide balance. Full-bodied, but a bit sharp on the tongue. An usuallually exciting German.

This is a very interesting beer. Poured into a snifter. Dark hazy brown body with a small beige head after an aggressive pour. No lacing. Smell is very much a weizen smell but more complex with the extra notes of dark fruits and high alcohol. Taste was very much a balance between the wheat bread and raisins with a creamy mouthfeel. A little on the higher carbonation which I dont like but thats the only negative thing I have to say about the taste. Now that it starts to warm up it gets even better. Also got some clove and brown sugar. Theres a decent bitterness to the end which balances the maltiness. Good beer and I will go get this again to share with others.

Awesome! God, awesome beer.

Dark fruit, malt aroma.
Decent head.
Amber, darker color.
Nice carbonation.
Raisin, plums, cherries, others.
Nice and sweet.

One of my favorite beers.

Pours a two-fingered light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving traces of lace. Cloudy brown/amber color, ton of yeast left in bottle. Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Malty dark fruit nose. Flavor is sweet raisins and alcohol, a very unusual eisbock.  $5.10 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

Aroma-sweet,cherries,plums.
melon, bread, some yeast/wheat.
fruity and rich like an English barley wine. Resiny on the tongue. Alcohol bite-more warming than anything. Sticky. Very sweet. Cough syrup.
Thick poor from bottle, nice persistent head.  Spicy, cloves, banana.  Nice carbonation for a high alcohol brew.  Luxurious body.  Nice, long spicy finish.

dark brown chocolate pour with a light tan head. lots of carbonation. sweet alcohol on the nose with a little bread and banana notes also. Slight bitterness mixed in with a chocolately bread flavor. very complex. gets better with each drink.

bottle thanks to angrypirate07.  chocolate brown with a cream head.  nose is clove, wheat, banana and alcohol.  nice thickness with a definite wheat, clove flavor and a very light hint of alcohol in the finish.
Deep amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of sweets, dark fruits and bubblegum. A flavor of dark alcohol, alcohol and sweets.

330 mL bottle.  Pours red brown with a big old off-white head.  Aroma is strong, sweet, and a bit boozy with lots of raisin, grape, cloves, and nuts.  Flavor is about the same, but smoothed out, with a pleasant combination of dark fruits, cloves, caramel, and nuts.  Im a bit surprised by the difference between this and regular old Aventinus.  Seems good to me!
*(on tap co2 and nitro mix)dark brown pour, with  big off white head. aroma of fruit esters. way darker the you would expect a wheat beer to be. i like it

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white tan head.  Aroma is sweet, alcohol, spices.  Flavor is sweet, with noticeable alcohol burn which is present, but pretty well hidden for being 12 percent. If I had to pick one next time I was in the store, Id just grab the regular Aventinus.
on tap at uber. dark brown, almost black pour with a significant malty sweetness to the nose and well balanced spices as well. Great palate and a smooth taste.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2009 Bottle thanks to TheJester. Dark, murky brown pour. Minty aroma with cloves banana and strawberries and butter. Taste is strawberry-banana with a well hidden alcohol. Mouthfeel is quite full and creamy with low carbonation. This beer tastes like an aged beer. Quite delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2016 Bottled 33cl. Murky brown appearance. Banana, glue and plum in the nose. Buttery. Full bodied. Sweet. Overrated in my opinon. I didnt enjoy it a huge deal. Rerate: I am not digging this beer. Staying with the initial rating.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 blurry dark brown with beige frothy head.
very sweet malty aroma, bursting with bananas foster with a bit of citrus and chocolate.
intense deep caramel banana flavor, chocolate grapefruit and lots of alcohol.
nice silky texture, mild carbonation.
this is good, but banana and alcohol dominate.

Wow. Bottle pours almost ice coffee with a medium diminishing head. Nicely cloudy look. Aroma is somewhat fruit and spice. Alcohol notes are in perfect harmony with the complexity Im not fully able to decipher. Simply fantastic.

Bottle pours a dark brown with a hint of amber and thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts, raisins, and plums.  Tastes sweet with a distinct alcohol finish and a very mild bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium-heavy body with low carbonation.  Interesting style but alcohol is the prevalant throughout this beer. I can imagine sipping this beer on a cold winter day and being warmed nicely.

Deep ruby/copper pour with a stunning creamy off-white head.
Aromas of caramel, red wine, port, caramelised bananas and wheat. Reminds me slightly of Trois Pistoles. Later on golden syrup, sultanas and chocolate become apparently. Lovely.
Intensely malty flavours with caramel and toasty notes, balanced with boozy alcohol and a light bitterness. Alcohol is a little over the top.
Big rich body, moderately high carbonation, higher than Id expect, but the flavour profile is so huge that this doesnt impact too much.

330ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma of raisins, dark ripe fruits, malts, light spices, slight banana, slight vanilla, slight caramel, light yeast, and some wheat.  Poured brown in color with a large, dense, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Opaque.  Slightly sparkling.  Complex flavor is medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of dark ripe fruit, light banana, bamburg wood, raisin, slight caramel, slight cloves, slight taffy, slight wheat, slight yeast, slight cocoa, and a hint of alcohol.  Medium to full body.  Creamy, slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Dark ripe fruit, slight banana, slight cocoa, and hint of spices.  12%ABV is virtually unnoticeable.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 Bottle 330 ml. Delicious brew. Aroma is raisin, port, vanilla, chocolate, and also fruitiness, maybe apple. Flavour is sweet, warmly alcoholic, and long lasting. Feels sticky and full-bodied, carbonation is adequate. Colour is dark brown; it has particles and residue, and the head disappears soon.
fruity/alcohol aroma. looks like swamp water. fruity raisin with clove and alcohol in the background taste. A very complex beer.

Bottle, 33cl, 2008. Pours dark, cloudy, yeasty brown with sediment. None to little head. Aroma of sweet malt, licorice and yeast. Similar on the palate, with prominent alcohol and some banana, and sharpish aftertaste. One for the cold winter nights!
Pours a very dark brown with some beige head, no lacing. Aroma is of toasted grains, nuts, slight fruit, and strong alcohol. Taste is comlex with grains, yeast, and strong alcohol.
Bottle. Pours deep dark mysterious brown with thin head. Aroma is spicy, taste is thick and sweet. Prime winter beer.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is a little bit spicy and features cinnamon, yeast concentrate, raisins and alcohol prominently. Tingly in the mouth, it has a lot of similarities with the original Aventinus, but a more powerful concentration of flavour. Malt, aniseed, clove and brown sugar are prominent but it does depend on the vintage and bottle. I have had other vintages which were a bit different but this one - 2009 - is definitely worth seeking out.
Had side by side with the normal Aventinus and liked it slightly less than the original.  Awesome story, though, and something every beer drinker should try!

On draft at the brickstore.  Pours a hazy light brown with fair ring of khaki head.  Nose is all wheat, and does not prepare you for the flavor explosion that is to follow.  Raisin, figs, caramel, anise, banana, clove, honey, and nice alcohol esters in the background that come off as cherries.  Medium full body with just the right amount of alcohol warming.  Most excellent!
Rich dark copper to brown pour., light of tan head. Dark Sugar/fruit scent among other things. Smooth taste. Cant believe its 12% Alc! Very good flavor and as I finish....I feel the 12%.

A nice dark brown pour, the color of mahogany with a 2" tan head.  Dark fruits, raisin bread, LME/malt syrup and caramel dominate the nose.  Huge wheat, malts, spices and dark fruits in the flavor.  It doesnt shy away from the sweeter side of things, which is a beautiful thing here.  Alcohol seems well under control and a secondary aspect of the beer. Great price too.
Bottle.Muddy brown colour with large beige head.Aroma of dried fruits and wheat sweet warming mouthfeels and slight spicey finish.

Pours a dark hazy brown.  Thin tan head that disspates quickly.  Aroma is raisins, figs and a hint of wheat.  Flavor is remarkable--dried chrerries, raisins, a hint of yeast and candi sugar.  If you didnt look at the label, youd thing you were drinking a good abt.  The mouthfeel is thick and coating (in a good way) and the alcohol, while warming, is very muted considering the ABV.  Basically, they took everything that was good about the original Aventinus and magnified it.  Truly awesome beer.

Crazy alcohol in this one...bit of a burn after the first sip accompanied by banana, yeast, and caramel malt.  Nose is sweet, but with out any really distinguishable aromas.  Flavor is toffee, brown sugar, and biting alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel.  Wouldnt get this one again.

Sampled in a 12 oz bottle. Pours dark and wow, full of incredible malts. Wow. It is incredibly intense. A really nice brew. This is a very well crafted brew. Aroma is semisweet. But the real part of this beer is its malts. They are absoluately fantastic.

pours a dark brown with a medium size tan head that goes away quickly, and some lacing.

smell of malt, syrup, cocoa, some caramel, some spice, and a little bit of roasted nuts.

taste is tangy, sour malt, nuts, spice, and a little bit of fruit, end is somewhat bitter.

Tap at PIB. Dark brown pour with a small white head. Aroma full of caramel, wheat, plum, raisins, clove, maybe cardomom. Flavor full of dark fruit, spice, roasted malts. Extremely tasty beer and I really need to try the original Aventinus soon.

Wow, what a great beer. Poures dark brown with a nice white head that is about 1/2 inch and slowly disapates. Amorma is rich with hints of  caramel, dark fruits (rasins, plums, etc.). Taste is awesome with a full body that lasts on the palate. The roasted malts, and other flavors mask the alcohol reministant of the better trappist ales. This beer rates with the best in my book.

Bottle 2006/01594; not exactly a collectable, so Ill photograph it and then get my dime from the bottle depot.  This poured with a decent sized off-white head, and this beer is quite dark, copper-coloured (maybe), and none too clear.  Hell, it was almost impenetrable when held up to the light.  Such a unique aroma, I dunno, my olfactory senses are sometimes useless in trying to decipher whats coming up to my nose from the glass.  I must take inspiration from my learned beer colleagues, and agree that aroma and taste both feature dark fruit such as plums and raisins.  Thanks, folks.  Likewise for spices.  Ive not a clue as to which.  Mouthfeel was smooooth, and the aftertaste was, well, to me like the flavour.  Pretty damned good beer for a special occasion, but not for everyday use.

11.2oz bottle: appearance is very dark brown with small cream color head, aroma filled with wheat and breaddy notes, flavor holy cow this packs a punch overwhelmed with wheat roasted malt and covers the alcohol well. all I can say is a damn good beer.
Bottle. Bottle. Appearance: Dark amber with a huge white head. Aroma: dark fruit, caramel and alcohol. Flavour: Dark fruit, caramel, spices and alcohol.

11-JUL-2009.
Bottle @home.
My first eisbock. I was expecting something much more syrupy, but was surprised. I had the normal Aventinus not long ago, and this is not to far from it.
Myddy brown with high beige head. I am a little surprised by that, becaus I thought high ABV would kill the head. but not in this case.
Nice nose with lots of fruits and malt - banana is there but so is the alcohol. I coud live with half the ABV.
Lots of weisse character with yeasty notes, and lots of carbonation.
Good beer and not too expensive, but I am not really convinced. Is this really bottom fermented beer?

Bottle. High creamy and lasting off-white head. Hazy muddy dark brown body. Banana apple pear aroma with clear indications of alcohol. Alcohol dominated fruity flavor with caramel and nuts. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste. Alcohol is way too dominant.

I cant believe the high rating of this beer, perhaps it has been better in the past, but I think people have been fooled by the power & maybe reputation.  Quite simply this beer is horribly unbalanced. On the palate the alcohol shows through at all times, like an ugly wino in your doorway. This leads to an unpleasant & hot sensation that unless its ice cold, renders the beer undrinkable for me.  Granted the nose is to die for, full malt, caramel & banana syrup, & these flavours do show up in the beer, but are constantly beaten with the hammer of that alcohol.  Its not that great beers cannot cope with 12%abv, this is just not one of them.

4 oz. taster at the Seattle IBF.  Pours dark brown with a white head.  Aroma of bread, vegetables, alcohol and sugar.  Flavor is sweet and grainy with a load of dark fruit and a touch of alcohol.  Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

12 oz bottle into snifter.  Very dark yet clear (if held to the light) reddish purple with a weird off-white/khaki tan head that fizzes like a soda and fades very rapidly to absolutely nothing -- no ring, no film, no-thing.  The aroma is very sweet.  I am not one for sweet beers traditionally, but this stuff smells great.  Belgian candi sugar, sweet dark fruits (red grapes, plums, cherries, etc), a but of tobacco, sherry,sweet malt, and more.  The flavor is, in its essence, good, but this one is just a bit over the top for me. Nice sweet fruity cherry and Belgian candy character, which is offset by the very hot alcohol burn.  The roastiness/tobacco malt quality doesnt seem to mesh very will with the sweet fruitiness, but is unmistakably these nonetheless. Alcohol is NOT hidden well. A bit musty on the finish. Medium bodied with minimal carbonation.  Overall: this is one of the more intriguing beers I have ever had.  It has so much potential -- started off really well and just sort of fell apart in the flavor.  Not horrible by any means, but much more enticing smell than flavor.  This could be awesome if it were only 8% instead of 12 --> too much "eis"ing, but interesting nonetheless.

Smells of dates, alcohol, grapes, has a wine-ish smell.  Pours translucent dark brown with no head.  Huge chunks of sediment and yeast.  Taste is surprisingly like a Trappist ale with some nice spice.  It has something on the tail end that is different though, perhaps its that lager purity.  Also, the fruitiness is sweeter than a Trappist ale.  Very good, right up to the last drop.

Bottle (dated 2008). Did not like this one though I suspect it may have been damaged as it was a bottle from last year. Poured a nice dark brown but was put off by the overly sweet and somehow off taste. Ended up not being able to finish this. Oh well, maybe its just not for me.
dark brown, rocky head with cloud and particles. a - sweet cloying banana, caramel. t - bitter hop introduced, walnut, fig, sweet chocolate. good desert beer.

Bottle (2009); and I thought Aventinus was perfect! Sweetish aroma, full of darker fruits along w/ the characteristic clove and banana flavors, albeit w/ the banana more toned down; pours a deep burgundy hued brown w/ a beige head; flavor carries forward the aroma, w/ the wheat notes taking centerstage again, swirling in a luscious mix of plums and sherry; slightly boozy, very full bodied and warming. Beautiful.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 Bottle. Great beer, I would rate it just slightly under their dunkel weizen. Pours a dark red colour with tan head . The flavour of caramel malts, clove, and figs. A bit overly sweet.
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Berry and wheat aroma. Also a sweet fruity taste, alcohol is hidden very well. An excellent beer.

12 oz bottle picked up in Athens at the Beer Factory.  Poured brown with a red hue and a medium sized tan head. Aroma of raisons, plums, other dark fruits with some caramel sweetness. Tastes sweet of dark fruits like raisons and plums. notes of caramel sweetness. Actually sort of tastes like raison bread.  Ive had other eisbocks, but I never realized this was where it all started.  Not bad.

Bottle thanks to a friend. I can see people enjoying this, but its just too much for me. Palate is immediately assaulted by copious amounts of sugar. The flavour is heavily masked by the sweetness, which is still a decent brew. Plums, sugar cane and honey are subtly lined under the strong sweet taste.

Pours red brown with a substantial tan coloured head. Nose has alot of depth and richness. Raisins, caramel with a heap of bready yeast and alot of spicy, clovey phenolics. Palate is quite full, showcasing the rich malt. Finishes with a big hit of abv and yeast driven spice. Quite complex, but the finish is a touch rough, especially once it warms up. Great beer, but certainly prefer the normal aventinus.
Bottle. Pours a muddled brown much like maple syrup with a body to match. Malty and sweet with hints of clove and alcohol.

aroma is plum/alcohol.  Pours very dark reddish brown.  Some kind of pulp floating around in there.  Taste is sweet, thick and smooth.  I love it.  I cant believe this beer is 12%. Bonus points for that.

Pours brown with no head. Aroma is vinous, sticky, and sweet with notes of plum, cloves and alcohol. Taste is plum, cloves, caramel, and a touch of alcohol which is warming in the stomach. Pretty thick and heavy for a wheat beer, and the carbonation is low. Im surprised by how much Im enjoying this considering I did not like the other Aventinus. Ill have to try that one again.
Tap at redlight.  Brown body.  Very complex and strong smell.  Lotta maltiness and yeast.  Also has a candy sugar sort of smell and taste.  Caramel malts were good. lot of alcohol in the taste.

11.2 oz. bottle from 2008.  Bottle #19155.  Pours a murky plum color with a huge and fizzy beige head.  A rich, complex aroma that features plenty of raisins, banana bread, cloves, cinnamon, caramel, and a yeasty/citrusy tanginess.  Big-bodied and syrupy, yet still kinda spritzy and refreshing due to the high level of effervescence.  TONS of sweet, candied sugar upfront taste-wise.  Banana bread, raisin, fig, clove, and cinnamon flavors follow.  Ends with some tangy oranges and a spicy bite.  Warming alcohol is present throughout.

Bottle, murky dark red brown color and a little tiny head, that puffs away. aroma is prunes, chocolate and syringa. flavor really complex with dark fruits, milk chocolate a little banana, orange marmalade. The alcohol is evident and a major player in this world class game

Dark brown, Very aromatic (fruit, yeast, alcohol, malt), good medium lasting head,  medium carbonation, not a very hoppy beer. A bit sweet (works well with its amount of alcohol). Good beer in general!

Bottle  Pours a murky brown with a big bubbly light tan head.  The head leaves rapidly.  Doent seem to be much lacing either.  Has a good aroma of fruits, nuts, caramel, and alcohol.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavors are good.  A big shot of the alcohol, but not a rough burn.  Lacks hops but is not too sweet.  Has a syrupy texture.  A good solid finish with a real good aftertaste.  This is a good beer.
bottle... not big on wheat beers or dopplebocks... but a very good rendition... that allows the dried fruit flavors to shine through but not be overpowering... a little too sweet for me...

Unclear dark brown, no head.

Aroma sweet, raisin.

Fizzy, medium body.

Alcohol not pronounced, no hopp. But not very sweet either.

 Not really my style. Too flat.

Purchased at New Beer Distributors, New York.
(Bottle) Smell and taste as the regular Aventinus but more intense (12% instead of 8.2%) and less smooth. Great beer.

Bottle. Thick opaque brown pour with a nice beige foamy head. Aroma of sweetbread, cinnamon, nice yeast presence, and some clove. Great aroma, I could smell this for hours. Flavor is cinnamon, yeast, bread, clove, raisins, dark fruits, great tasting beer! The mouth feels like gargling with syrup! Excellent beer.

bottle, pours hazy amber with a tall light tan head.  Sweet yeasty aroma with some bannana and wheat.  Some good bready malt notes that have a carmel sweetness and end with a light alcohol burn and a little bit of a spice bite.  Not bad.

Bottle. Dark brown with small frothy, lacing tan head. Aromas off sweet dark malts, nuts, yeast, banana, orange, caramel and alcohol. The flavour is sweet and warming with notes of dried fruit, caramel, spices, orange peel and sugar. Well balanced powerfull stuff. Great dessert beer.

Bottle.  Nose is yeast, alcohol, malts, and plum.  Taste is caramelized figs, plum, clove, spice, and yeast.  Full bodied and chewy with a strong sugary finish.  Large amounts of alcohol present.. but it works in its favor if consumed as a sipper.  The best way to describe would be the delicious classic, Aventinus, with a half shot of bourbon.

This beer is everything the regular Aventinus is and more. Its so much more intense than the regular 8.2% counterpart.
The aroma gets you going...malty, caramel, toffee, chocolate, banana, slight bit of hops....mmmmmm...

Very thick, fluffy head that looks like a 
Whoppers Malted milk ball.

Raisin, prune, banana, chocolate...pretty much it tastes how it smells. The hops are overwhelmed by the flavor.

Best dark(er) beer EVER.
really good shit lots of nice smooth flavors and packs a punch ......................................

Bottle (330ml) Cellared for 3 years. Poured intense dark ruby with a small, frothy, lightly tanned head which was mostly diminishing. A rich, sticky, complex aroma with burnt sugar, toffee, toasted malts, dark chocolate, muscatels, prunes, caramelized dates and allspice. Flavor was of rich sticky toffee with caramelized dates, rum & raisin chocolate, fruit cake, figs, sultanas, brown sugar, light woody notes, a touch of port and a warming finish. Well hidden alcohol, very smooth with virtually no bitterness. Full bodied with very soft carbonation, a syrupy texture and a long lasting finish.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 Quite a complex beer. Aroma is heavy with notes of plums, raisins, chocolate, wheat and very light alcohol....almost like a fine port. Flavor is similar, with dark fruits and a chocolate palate, followed by a fantastic alcohol warmth. Mouthfeel is smooth. Overall, a delicious brew to be enjoyed on a cold winter night,or any cool night when needed that elusive alcohol warmth.

Murky brown pour, as if I had a snifter full of river water, with a tan head rimming the glass. More lace than a virgin bride on her wedding day. Aroma of striking your nose in a bag a prunes. Some banana, and yeast. A bit of alcohol. Flavor is thick and chewy, a thick heavy malt bill thats fruity and estery, leaves your mouth dry. Alcohol notes but nothing like youd expect from such a high ABV. Lots of chunks at the bottom of the glass. A wheat eisbock? Awesome.

This opaque brown ale poured with a generous beige head that dwindled away in a few minutes. There is a strong fruit and spice aroma, notably banana, plum and cloves. After a couple sips, there is a peppery sensation on ones tongue and throat. This is a very interesting brew that is a delight to drink.

Eyes. incredible cream coffe head. goood carbonation and yellow burn color
Nouse: Aroma was citrus, clove, frutal banana aroma. 
Tonge: The flavor is good and very complex. Many fruity notes malt wheat yeast and citrus. it is very cream and smooth. 
Very Niceee

Serving type: bottle

33cl Bottle. Dark brown color , medium brown head that quickly dissolves. Sweet aromas of raisins,plums,port wine, some wheat. Full bodied wit complex flavour that is pretty well balanced even if it is a bit on the sweet side for my taste. Very decent.

Pours and dark amber with fleeting off-white head. Fruity aroma with hints of raisin, malt, banana and other sweet goodness.  Lots of flavor going on here. Sticks to the tongue.   A great full bodied beer!

Super aventinus concentrate is pretty damn fine idea. Port vineous nose, banana and cloves once again and hugely malty surge when you gulp it down. Kicks ass, on par with the normal aventinus which is saying something.

Bottle, bought at the bierkoning. Very nice beer. fluffy off-white head. Aroma of dark fruit and yeast. Flavor is spicy, dark fruits and alcohol.

Overall very good beer :).
Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma of dark fruit and yeast. Flavor is spicy, dark fruits and alcohol. Good beer.

Bottle.  Poured a deep chestnut color, light brown head.  Nose is sweet rasins, plums and yeast.  Thick mouthfeel decent carbonation.  Flavor is very Belgian-like rasins, plums, yeast, spice, and sweet alcohol all present.  Too much alcohol to taste any wheat in it.  Finished sweet and slightly sour.

Bottle dated 2008.  Pours a dark, clear brown with yeast floaties and a thick tan head that quick disappears to a slight ring around the glass.  Aroma of wheat malts, dried fruits (raisins, prunes, bananas), and alcohol.  Taste is no surprise with a bit of sweetness and roasted malt thrown in.  Mouthfeel is slightly creamy with a pleasant aftertaste that I find hard to describe.  Overall a very heavy body with a lot of complexity.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into its own Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock glass. The bottle was numbered and dated 2007.

Appearance: The pour is smooth, thick and builds a tall tan head. The head quickly settles down to thin wispy layer that is slick and leaves no lacing behind. Its body is thick, cloudy, brownish in color and contains some small bits of yeast sediment floating in it. 

Smell: The nose is big deep and fruity. Wheat malt notes are surrounded by over ripe banana peel and raisons soaked in rum.

Taste/Mouth feel: Its flavor like its aroma is big and deep as well. Concentrated sweet malty flavor is full warming alcohol, mild clove and fruity yeast showing raison, banana peel, prune and bubble gum like flavor notes. The texture was slick and smooth with slightly syrupy, but not overly so, mouth feel. Carbonation is light in this big full bodied beer.

Notes: This beer is big, bold, and beautiful.

this one really confused me. it tastes very similar to an abt. 12 like st. bernardus. not so much wheat or bock flavors but rather a lot of raisin and fruity flavors. doesnt really have the flavors of a typical eisbock but its still a great brew!

appearance is wonderful nearly opaque rich red hue with a perfectly floating consistent head that wiggles like scum riding on a fresh batch of simmering chicken stock. nose has the MO to some extent of a good dubbel: raisins, pit fruits and prunes, all with a good dose of caramelization and a wave of booze riding behind them. even as head recedes, carbonation continues to pop. plenty of yeast chunks and other chunks of unknown origin dance through out the bottom of my chalice.  flavor continues to parallel my favorite belgian dubbels, rich flavors that threaten to delve into red wine territory. earthy and rich, and quite substantial. booze is present but not at all offensive, simply warming in the most basic way and not intrusive on the many complex notes in the flavor. amongst it all, it maintains the trademarked weizen mouthfeel: soft and coating. it is possibly the most interesting element to this very intreguing beer, a straightforward sharp mouthfeel would possibly constitute a strike against it and would make the big ABV more noticeable. as it stands this is possibly the grandfather of all big beers. wildly complex and worthy of discussion for long spells.

[1867-20081123] 11.2floz bottle. Rich heavy rum raisin malt aroma with a rum currant fruit cake throughout. Hazy, brown red body with a quick head. Boozy rum raisin malt fruit cake flavour that finishes burnt. Medium-full body. Super boozy, not to my taste but still fair.

Pours a light rootbeer like brown with white particulate and beige head that stuck around for a few minutes. Aroma is plummy raisin with some undetectable spice. Taste is also dark fruit but now the clove spice and some banana shine through. I feel the alcohol taste is muted but still there. Very warming. Feel is full and sticky and satisfying. Very interesting beer and I thank Elgaucho for    helping me pick it out at the Four Firkins in St. Louis Park, MN. Bottle 2008/27717

Nice root beer color with lots of floaty bits.  Molasses and toffee aroma with some rubbing alcohol.  Burnt sugar and holiday spice married to deep, dark forest fruits.  Also some good sour, a small bitter, and continuous alcohol warmth.  Cant help but mention premium cough syrup, because it is there, not because it detracts.  One worth keeping on hand.

Appearance:  A dark, murky reddish brown with white floaties dancing around in it. A quickly disapated head leaves behind a trail of gathering bubbles at the top.

Aroma:  Belgian-like yeast, dark fruit, cloves, and other spices. Also a nice alcohol presence.

Taste: Dark fruits, Belgian-like yeast, cloves, and a modest touch of hops.

Mouthfeel: Sticky.

Overall: A real sipper than makes you curious.  Lots of stuff going on in this beer. Very tasty.

11.2 oz bottle (1st of this style Ive tried).  Very pleasant and full aroma, fresh bananas and cream, clove, toffee wheat bread, cinnamon spice, and only minor alcohol with a big whiff.  Nice pour as well, thick, large bubbled cream head, a very nice layer of retention, opaque but not overly thick looking, and dark honey brown in color.  The first thing noted upon drinking is how smooth and creamy tasting this beer is for the abv.  Theres definitely a strong bite to it, but nice rich flavors accompany it along the way to not let this negatively impact the experience.  The flavor notes are rather similar to a combo of both a well made weiss and doppelbock with good banana, spices, yeast, and light citrusy hops on the wheat side, and cookie dough and rich toffee/caramel malts on the bock side.  Its interesting to me that these flavors come out quite separately with each sip rather than blended together.  The final product though is a very good quality, and strong German brew. Not too bad at all.

Pours a dark brown with some chunky sediment noticed when holding it up to the light. A thin tan head rapidly dissipated. It has a rather sweet fruity aroma - also noticed the alcohol immediately in the aroma aswell. A full bodied beer, it even feels quite thick when in the mouth, syruppy even. Spicy fruity/banana flavours. Can taste the alcohol in the aftertaste. Although I recognise this as being a good beer I found it a little to sweet for my taste and I found it dificult to finish the beer. A good beer though by all means with a dry, and slightly bitter finish. - 330ml brown bottle.

Bottled. Aroma has banana, raisin, spices. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an oof-white head. The taste is sweet has spices like clove and laurel. Toffee, caramel malts in it and some fruitiness. good beer i think.

This is the darkest weat beer I have ever had, that being said, it tastes like a prune0juice lambic. kind of nasty, but still fun to try, I think I am done with it, tho. $5.99 per 12oz bottle at Sunset Corners Miami

bottle from LCBO. From notes, aroma is yeasty and dry fruits. Taste is quite sweet. Pretty much like the regular Aventinus. Note sure if I liked it better though. Well hidden alcohol content. Rating #74

33cl Bottle at Gollem 2. Dark reddish brown colour, beige head. Aroma of brown sugar, liquorice root, dark malts and fruits, alcohol. Flavour is sweet, malty, a little dark fruits, brown sugar, alcohol. Smooth and easy drinking, medium to fullbodied.

07 bottle:  Pour was a dark mahogany with a thick, tan head.  Nose was massive amounts of dark fruits, i.e. raisins, plums, etc.  Some dark malted wheat is apparent along with some spice.  Great carbonation on this yet it still retains some silkiness in the body.  Flavor was the aforementioned dark fruits, wheat and spice.  Very good brew.

Did an alright job of hiding the alcohol, but the flavors were very nice. Similar spice, caramel and fruity flavors to the regular. I like the drinkability and more subtle flavors of the original, but this is still pretty good.

I actually prefer this to the regular Aventinus, but theyre both so damn good, who really cares?  Ultra-intense flavors, its almost hard to describe.  I was actually shocked (in a good way) when I first sipped this beer.  I was unaware you could pact that much explosive flavor into any liquid.  You can definitely taste the alcohol, but its a nice compliment rather than an unpleasant surprise.
It does have an alcohol flavor mixed with a wheat and strong beer flavor.  Enjoyable.  To be sipped and savored.  Easy to drink at 12% alcohol.  Very dark spice and flavor!

Apperance: Hazy red/brownish with a decent sized head. No lacing at all.

Aroma: Fruit, Caramel, Malt, Alcohol, Yeast.

Flavor: Caramel, Malt, Cloves, Fruit, Yeast, Alchohol, Spices.

Palate: Very sweet and sticky with lots of sweet malt and fruit. Some taste of alcohol at the end. Warms you up nicely!

The normal Aventinus is great and this is a concentraded version if it, cant go wrong with that. Very good stuff!
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 For Aventinus lovers this is heaven. Same great taste just a boosted ABV%. Surprisingly easy drinking for 12%

I am a huge fan of the original Aventinus.  The eisbock version is amazing as well.  The concentration of flavor is outstanding, and even though its 12% you cant really taste or feel the alcohol on the palate.

An amazing amount of sediment and gunk at the bottom of this three-month-cellared bottle which retains most of the great spice and stewed fruit flavors of the regular Aventinus, presenting them anew in greater concentration and depth. Outstanding.

Pours a dark caramel color with a small fizzy head that disappears immediately. It has a tart nose of yeast and dark fruits cherries and prunes. Dark fruity flavor as well with yeast and dried fruits. The sweetness is tempered  by a little hop bitterness (spicyness) in the end.
