Quite strong alcoholic and malty aroma. Quite carbonated. Some sour feeling  combined with the sweetness. Heavy mouthful. Some roasted dryness. Actually allright, but the wheaty notes makes it a bit sharp and untasty.

Intensely clovey aroma (yum!) with some banana, rye bread and vanilla.
Tastes less sweet than regular Aventinus - perhaps the alcohol makes it appear drier. Quite a bit of alcohol but it works well. 
Can't help but compare it to the un-eis version and I think I prefer this. The eis is probably a bit more simple (ie. less going on) but the less sweet flavour agrees with me.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Bottle 17206.  Deep brown, nice head that faded completely.  Huge aroma of cloves, almost biting, smelled like a Pigface concert.  Decent malty flavors, more clove accents, a bit of bite on the tongue.  Not my favorite style overall, but well done.  Alcohol is clearly there, bit of a burn from it.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2004 Bottle # 024604. Served in a very cool glas!! Tall beige head on a deep brown body. Nose of fruit, banana, malt and some alcohol. Flavor is sweet at first but turns to a nice hoppy bitterness. Flavor is fruity with blackcurrant. Maybe a little too much alcohol to the aftertaste. Nice and interesting. It hits you like a rollercoaster!!
Smells nice and yeasty/banana...Wicked hazy red/brown.Tastes intense.Nice sharp 11% on the tongue.Gentle beast of a beer considering...

Bottle # 010586.  Well I opened this bottle, fresh from my celler @ 55F, and made a mess on my desk.  Lots of carbonation.  Head settled quickly.  Big aroma of bananas, yeast and glue or nail polish remover, (hey they both smell good). Or perhap bubble gum.  Color is a hazey, ruby-brown.  Taste is rich with malts, sugar and that bubble gum flavor.  Finish is dry and like a wheat beer.  Leaves a tingle in the mouth.

Bottle (#007845).  A dark cloudy brown color with a tan head.  Strong alcohol presence in the aroma with raisins, dark fruits, and a nice spice. Piercing warm alcohol in the flavor with a thick coating fruity finish.

very intense.  alcohol is present, but no liquor tasting, more filling the mouth and feeling it down your throat.  surprisingly and pleasantly smokey in aroma and taste.  the strength, smoke, and sweetness of the wheat makes this a must try.  though best shared.  ouch!
Dark brown coloured. Very cool glass. Huge banana aroma. Yeasty, wheaty and alcoholic flavour. Nasty.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 Sampled both one and two year old vintages. Murky dark brown body with notable viscosity and a thin fizzy head. Contains, large, scary chunks that resemble flecks of clay. Fragrant malty aroma includes raisins, roasted figs, molasses, and ethanol. Flavor is of prunes, cola, yeast, and high octane alcohol. Syrupy mouthfeel. Makes me think Im drinking a prune juice and Coke cocktail. I much prefer other eisbocks like Kulmbacher and Castle Eggenberg over this one.
Dark brown color with a greyish head. The taste is nice wheat malty with notes of yeast, fruit and alcohol.

Thanks to bigbadbear63.  Nice dark brown color, fruity, sweet, and somewhat warm aroma.  I tasted some candy sugars, fruit, and alcohol.  The finish was nice and smooth, with a hint of sweetness.  I enjoyed this beer quite a bit.

The aroma is sweet of raisins, fruit, plums, and very faint hints of wheat. The color is a clear brown and it has a beutiful light brown head - and is served in a very beutiful glass.  The flavor is very sweet with notes of raisins, wheat, plums, and other fruits - a little too sweet for me. It ends on slightly wheaty note with the alcohol hitting you right in the end - but then it gives you warmth in the cold of winter. It has a good palate.

Dark brown with red glints. White head. Aromatic, fruity nose: plums, raisons, currents, black cherries and alcohol.  Flavor is raisons, figs, currents and candy sugar. Goes down smoothly for a high octane beer.

Bottle 007787 11.2 oz- Deep cloudy dark chestnut color with some burnt reddish hints in its highlights, a nice tannish head appeared puffy and whipped tight becoming crusty but faded fast to a thick fluffy ring around the edge, lace in fast drippy sheeting. Holy phenolic nose with alcohol! Some major band-aid plastic and vitamin coating phenols flying all around a big ethanol heated alcoholic smack, with hints of some dark fruits and malty sweetness that can be sensed just before the alcohol or after a long time of off the rim sniffing. Taste is very nice and malty sweet with nice subtle complexities. A good load of fruityness both ripe and dried variants that contain some plum, raisin, and dates and there's a wonderful caramel smoothness coming into the finish lingers some; but that start is quite complex in the wheats, malts, and fruits with a pleasant mesh of everything. The midway point has a good little hop bitterness and building point which then lightly soothes out to a nice mellow finish of caramel which is very congenial and has some nice little agreeable plastic yeasty notes that never overwhelm as so does the alcohol which sits behind it all waiting to take charge upon bigger gulps and slightly burn with a spiced alcohol. Feel is pretty thick and chewy, nearly full, smooth for sure with a favorable creamyness and alcoholic edgeyness in its finish. Smooth drinking, but watch for that eye drooping alcohol, I'm sleepy...What a nice brew. Nose was a bit much on the plastic, but the flavors and ABV make up for it; head swimmingly delicious!

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2003 Beautiful thin head of fine rotating bubbles.  Great carbonation causes a small eddy in the glass making the head swirl and recirculate.  Wonderful aroma.  Multiple layers grapes, raisins, sweet malts and a whiff of alcohol.  Color is a murky  dark mahogany brown.  Lots of sediment in the bottle.  Flavor is rich and malty with some more grapes.  Flavor is not as complex as the aroma but still quite nice.  Strong kick of alcohol in the end that leaves a tingling sensation on the tongue and a warming sensation as it goes down.  Quite reminiscent of a fine brandy.  A top quality beer that is not for the weak and perfect for a nightcap.

Brown-red beer; pours with a good yellow head, but gone in secs. Very fruity nose, really - fruity-alcoholic I ought to say. Not necessarily banana. Bit of leather, however. Typical German bread taste, laced with brandy to the very gills, and maybe very ripe pears. Very high carbonation, making it appear even less full-bodied than it really is. Yet the alcohol returns with a vengeance. An impressive brand, no doubt. But it is not something I'm going to rave about. Professionaly made - for export.

Deep mocha body with chunks of yeast floating about, small head.  Spice and clove in the nose with a good amount of alcohol.  Flavor bursting with cloves and banana.  Finishes smooth and very warm with alcohol fumes flowing into the sinuses.  I'm glad my local store finally starting carrying this.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2004 Pours quite amazing. I watched as the huge sediment chunks were sucked upwards with the bubbles and then slowly floated back only to repeat the process.  Deep chocolate, muddy brown. Bottle conditioned? Oh ya.  Good beige-rich yellow head.  Smells of a good amount of crisp hops upon opening. Wow. Slowly overpowered by the nice spicy wheat and bananas/clove aroma.  Alcohol as well.  Opens up with lots of alcohol. Very strong beer.  As it warms and breathes, it becomes quite similar to the weizenbock with more alcohol, and less wheat taste.  Still a bit watery at the finish, but maybe some more chocolate flavors become more easily detectable.  I would be interested to try some cellared eisbock as I would agree the young eisbock is better than their young weizenbock (if you can get past the alcohol).
This is even better than Aventinus if you can handle the higher alcohol and syrupy taste.  For a daily drink, regular aventinus is probably better.

Looks like cloudy sewerage water with lumps of dehidrated smeg in it. But don't let that put you off, it's tastey. Complex. Smells fantastic. It's got a slightly aggresive effervescense about it. Kinda sweet inital taste that doesn't linger. The warmth off the alcohol is mellowing to the most ferocious beast. Gotta have more. Do it.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 (Obviously a bad bottle last time) 2011 re-rate: poured into a tulip glass. A deep purple brew. Low head, decent carbonation. Aroma of sweet prunes, faint alcohol nose, but not too bad. Heavy, complex flavor, but very smooth and drinkable. Well balanced. Much better as it warms. Time for a nap!

Dark brown color with light head and no lacing (actually more than I would expect for this high of an ABV). The aroma is lightly hoppy with a cherry, bockish quality to it. One aroma stands out that doesn't quite please me is a fresh outhouse smell. The flavor is lightly sweet with complex malt and yeast filling out the back. Some fruity flavors are there with a pear, raisin end to the flavor. Finishes with a nice alcohol sting and warmth feeling. Overall this had an almost positive and negative aspect compared to the regular aventinus.

Pours a cloudy amber with a thin head that barely covers the beer, and has some spotty lacing. Aroma is shocking to the nose. Eyes almost started watering. Nose has a small undertone of fruit and then an assault of strong alcohol, something sharp and not pleasing at all. Thankfully, the nose isn't really associated with the flavor which is actually quite enjoyable. Warm on the way down, malt and fruit are in the aroma. Sticky palate, but isn't too cloying. If not for the aroma, I would have enjoyed this beer more.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2003 I give this one slightly higher marks for being unusual. Dark beer, thick and lasting head. Alcohol aroma. Rich and malty, with strong alcohol. The alcohol feels cooling as the beer passes over the tongue and seems to evaporate into the brain.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: About what I expected. Thinnish on the tongue- I really would have loved some more body. But no doubt that this is what is advertised- a super sweet version of the great Aventinus.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2004 vibrant, deep copper body, foamy, light brown head.  Barley corns, chocolate, carmel.  a small dose of phenols.  Smooth, yeasty and sweet initially.  then effervescent and astingent.  yeast returns on finish. Mildly roastey and pretty strong.
RE_RATE summer 2004: man, I underestimated my liking of this beer.  Intensely fruity nad complex nose.  Beautiful radiant body.  wonderful warmth!

Hazy, dark brown lager. Big, fizzy, tan head.
Crazy nose! Banana and bubblegum followed by notes of licorice, light perfume, mint and sassafras.
The flavor is a medley of Drambuie and sweet caramel.
Medium-bodied with an oily/syrupy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation.
Lengthy, grassy, alcoholic finish. Leaves the tongue a bit numb and oily. Odd, but very enjoyable.

Bottle No. 022315. Pours with a big fluffy tan head and a deep caramel color. Aroma is the same as the weizen bock (regular Aventinus). Banana, coriander. Flavor is the same as well with well pronounced wheatiness. Overall a great beer with a huge alcohol bite to it.

First encounter with an eisbock and I'm hooked.  Deep brown and murky, nice fluffy wheat beer head with just the right amount of carbonation.  This is certainly the big bro of their standard weizenbock.  Smooth caramel, banana, clove, brown sugar, fruity, and a hint of vanilla.  Very rich buttery notes are thrown in for good measure.  Good complexity from start to finish.  A must try!

12 oz bottle pours the color and murkiness of prune juice with a good head.  Fruity aroma with some spiciness.  The flavor is fruity and wheat like and yeasty with some clovyness and a banana showing.  The palate is good and rich.  I like this.

It's eisbockity! You may quot me on that if you dare. Will have to get my hands on this again to do a side by side comparison w./ the regular Aventinus. (regular Aventinus - that's an oxymoron, right?) Pretty much feel the same way about this as I do about the other and that is feeling that it is quite an exceptional beer. My favorite part of drinking it is having one ordered for another felow at the table and seeing a wave "bye bye" from cohort at the table. Yep, it's hefty. One big YUM.

Dark brown and murky. Big bubbled off-white head. Big fruit and clove aroma - hint of alcohol. Buttery, fruity, spicy on taste. Huge carbonation blast up front that has gone leaving a smooth and creamy, but fairly flat elixir. The alcohol hits right off the bat, which of course makes me extremely partial to this beer.

Pours with intense carbonation and chunky bits of sediment.  Deep orange-light brown colour with cloudy appearence.  Phenolic/alcoholic aroma.  Banana, yeatsy , clove flavours.  Sticky/thick mouthfeel.  Intriguing

Bottled: Hazy dark brown coloured. Very quickly diminishing head. Aroma is fruity, yeasty, full of alcahol with some distinct rum characthers. Flavour is dominated by the rum.  Some fruity notes (plums) and yeast as well. Is quite warming and has a long lasting at the palate. Superb alcaholburnt in the end. Nice one. Thanks Raindog.

Bottle 011124. Aroma of chocolate, clove/banana and toasted malt. Hazy dark brown with light tan head that fades to a slight collar. Falvor is chocolate banana up frront, which steps aside for huge alcohol and malt. Tail is phenol and alcohol. very warming.

Was surprised to come back to Australia and find out they had started to import this. Really nice beer. Lots of vanilla, chocolate, banana, wheat, yeast. Smooth soft palate, with some alcohol in the finish. Quite pleasant to drink.

bottle 12570, year 2002. Pours deep dark brown with a tan head. Strong aroma of caramel, plum, banana, and yeast. Initial flavor of malt and wheat takes a back seat to the alcohol finish. A good beer on its own, just doesn't hold up to the original Aventinus.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2006 Pours out a huge head, no lacing, aroma of banana thought the colour was of dark mud. Banana comes through in the taste also malt and caramel, alcohol is there but not offensive! Cheers!

Sampled at From The Vine monthly beer tasting Aug 4th, 2003: Pours a dark amber-brown with a medium beige head and thin lacing. Pours a dark brownish-amber with a medium beige head and thin lacing. Aroma of sweet cherry, banana and cloves. Kind of rich, with a strong malt and alcohol presence over the wheat. This style is still somewhat of a mystery to me. Like a cross between malt liquor and a Weiss? The alcohol is very noticeable throughout. The finish is malty and fruity (plum). Definitely worth a return visit.

Nice one. Not so good as the regular stuff regarding body and balance, but the kick of alcohol is way cool and just a weird idea considering the regular stuff isn't exactly a light. Interesting stuff, the sultanas are still there, but the watties baked beans are gone. Thanks goes to Ecz on this one. Cheers mate.

I was recommended this one by the fine people at Premier Gourmet, so I snatched up a bottle. The colour of the beer was a nice dark brown colour with a slight purple haze, but that could have been from seeing it on the bottle's label :-). The smell is simliar to Aventius, grapey, malty and even chocolatey. Full-bodied, malty, fruity and definateliy alcholic tasting. The aftertaste is almost purely alcoholic, but not burning or harsh in any way. This is one that is spot on with the commercial description, basically a more intense Aventius, but it works out pretty nicely! I really liked the Aventius in the first place, and I think this was good, but I probably would prefer the original 9 out of 10 times, still. One definately to try, especially if you've never had an Eisbock! I bought this bottle at Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.

as you would expect, a thicker, more intense and much more obviously alcoholic version - aventinus concentrate. really full-on salty, estery, chocolatey, rummy flavours and aromas + that fat sweet taste of pure alcohol in the finish. pretty hard to drink, but i gotta give it marks for big flavour.

Murky red brown with large but quickly dissipating cola-like-bubbled beige head. Strong but pleasant esters, bready yeast n malt aroma, Luscious smooth quite low carb body. Big fruity wheaty malt flavours. High alcohol is very well masked. As others have said, this one is not as fully entertaining as the straight Aventinus but nevertheless a very nice  winter warmer.

The foreboding look and aroma of this beer is not let down by its fat mouthfeel and warmth going down. Bananas and cloves are evident and the aftertaste is pleasant and not too cloying. The Aussie label says that this is 3.1 standard drinks, so one of these and you are catching the cab home. This is a real winter warmer, Cascade brewery take note.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Enormous banana bouquet, yeast, malt, caramel and spicey aromas. Auburn  colour, very small, tight toffee head, with plenty carbonation. Intense banana flavour, very malty, yeast and clove taste as well. Alcohol is present, but not overly so, malty aftertaste. Full bodied, rich texture, an extremely warming beer. Top notch!
UPDATED: JUL 25, 2003 Nice sweet wheat aroma,  Color is a dark clowded brown.  Got a good deal of cream head with it.  Flavor is a nice and rather sweet and quite smooth.

Pours with a deep amber brown body topped by a medium thick off white head that leaves a good amount of lacing.  Slightly sweet yet sour fruity (banana?)aroma with some alcohol and a touch of yeastiness.  Slightly sweet malt flavor with notes of clove, banana and yeast with a strong alcohol presence.  Full bodied, almost numbing on the tongue and very warming.

Tan head, short lived. Comes right back with a slight swirl, purty. Big fruity nose with some licorice and tobacco notes. Creamy mouthfeel, med/full body. Slick on the tongue. Some bananna flavors as well as some bready, grainy notes, some chocolate and vinous flavors also. The 11% alc. is well hidden. Damn nice brew! Gotta get some to lay down.

Rich, creamy, complex. Beautiful/thick/lasting head. Chocolate aroma somehow, along with spiced apples and a bit of banana. Raisin and currant flavors reminded me of (tasty) dark fruitcake. Slight alcohol edge of the rum-soaked fruitcake that my Baptist grandmother speaks longingly of.

2002 Vintage: Bottle #14727Dark, muddy, murky brown color. The head began as large (big bubbles) and beige, and quickly diminished into nothing. Definitely banana in the nose...some alcohol, spiced apples, sugary malt. The flavor was very sweet, apples, bready, acidic, banana, alcohol in the aftertaste. Soft feel, thick, very wet finish.

magnificent product in it's dapper purple pinstripe bottle.  cloudy yellow-chestnut, a crumbled  civilization of yeast drifting within. head is too wet to lace but ebbs and sags to a small sparrow-tan colored ring. aroma of banana bread with sweet buttery raisin pear filling, clean smelling and emanating great strength.  gentle with holiday spices, prodigious potency, apple in dank noble rot, silky carbonation and enough bitterness to preclude runaway sweetness.  flavors combine like a baked dessert   with a warming sauce of rum soaked raisins and a squeeze of lemon.  a pinacle creation among weizens.
Brown color with tiny bubbles that release the aroma of clove and a nice malt character.  The flavor has clove, raisin and plum with noticable alcohol.  A very good beer.

Soft walnut brown with a vanialla coloured head.  Tiny bubble fiz through my glass continuously while I drink. . . Large malty aroma with some alcohol, raisins, bananas and cloves.  Spicey flavour, laced with alcohol, rich nuts, great malt.  Clean woody/malt finish.

A decent-looking eisbock with a dark copper body, but only at tiny lacing of bubbles.  An astringent alcohol bite to the finish that warms you as do the various other winter spices.  Plums and even prunes here.  High alcohol nose.  Stong malts in the flavor.

Wow, this is much better than "regular" Aventinus, of course, I'm one of the few people that have rated that beer pretty low - this has a hugh aroma of alcohol, caramel and cloves - the appearance is a burnt copper, the head/lacing is very small, but that's expected in such a high alcohol brew - the clove flavor that is so noticable in "regular" Aventinus is present, but there is a lot more going on in this beer - the malty sweetness is magnified, but it is not at all a cloying sweetness - there are some fruit flavors in this, like raisins, and perhaps cherries - I can taste some hints of brown sugar as well - the alcohol is noticable, but not overpowering - it just gives a tingling sensation on the palate that easily grows on you - even if you don't care for Aventinus, or think it's over-rated, you should still give this one a try - you might get a nice surprise.

This brew poured a large tan head. There was not very much lacing on the sides of my mug. Carbonation was observed rising to the top. It had a clove aroma to it. The body was brown. It was a smooth tasting drink and definitely one to sip and not guzzle.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew poured a large invigorated head of creamy light brown small to medium sized bubbles with an opaque brown body. The head lasted a fairly long time but left no lacing. It has a mild malty aroma with a hint of its high alcohol content. It also has a ery strong burnt roast flavor without the smoke. You can feel the alcohol hit even after the first couple of tastes. Not a brew you can drink too many of in a sitting. I agree with an earlier post about the high alcohol content tingle this brew produces. I think I would prefer a smoother beer without this tingle.

This has truly so many flavors very complex but balanced very well.  The alcohol taste is hidden well...kind of surprising that it is 11%.  Overall great appearance, nice aroma...very smooth with a little fizziness.  This is one to keep around!!
UPDATED: DEC 8, 2006 Cloudy brown,lasting beige head.Banana malt nose.Yeasty bibblegum , plum taste. Fizzy, with medium alcohol bite
Good malt nose, followed by a good balance of malt and alcohol throught .  A definite sipper.

Shall I write a poem?  Can I paint you a picture?  Artistry is needed to capture the wondrous quality of this beer's appearance--the best that I can recall seeing for a very long time indeed.  Pours a lovely murky chestnut color, and the head is incredible.  It is perhaps the first head that I've seen that actually increases after the pour before settling down (but remaining).  The carbonation in a good glass (I used a Oberdorder Weissbier pilsner glass, don't know if that was a faux pas) consisted of layers of extremely small streams of bubbles, rising oh-so-slowly in the glass.  Elegant and attractive.  The aroma was bold, reminding me of a Belgian double, with raisin, banana, and a hint of clove.  The flavor and palate are affected by a sharp bite of the alcohol--perhaps the most noticeable "flaw" here, if that kind of raw alcoholic tingle bothers you.  There is also an attractive creaminess to this provided by the strong malt base, and as it clings to the tongue whiffs of flavor hang around for a long finish.  Oh yes, I enjoyed this beer, despite the faults which may prevent this from being regarded as the cream of the crop.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2008 Pours a murky ruby brown with a well-proportioned off-white head.  Aroma is similar to Aventinus, like swimming in a pool of sweet malted wheat along with some lemony citrus and bready yeasty notes. Good complexity in the body.  Flavors include milk chocolate, vanilla, clove and citrus with even a hint of smoke.  Very smooth and hides its alcohol masterfully well, at least until it reaches my stomach and warms me up.  Perhaps just a step behing Aventinus in its drinkability, but still a world-class brew.

(Draft) Truly amazing, in appearance and in the mouth. Delightful hazy chocolate-wheat appearance, with a unique shading towards yellow where the light penetrates it beneath a fluffy head. Flavor an explosion of pecans and bananas, exotic and delightful. Satisfyingly strong, still drinkable - the delicate feel of this beer demands savoring indulgence, if only to master its complexity...
Acomples malty nose with alcohol evident. Auburn body with light head. Malt predominants and the brew doth warm the innards.
I am a HUGE Aventinus fan, I feel they brew the best beer around.  This one is no exception, very complex and drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2005 Muddy brown, nearly black. Off-white, mostly lasting head leaves spots of lace. Hard-hitting aroma of yeast, sweet malts, and raisin. A sharp bite up front. This beer never lets up. Explosive wheaty, yeasty, malty flavor. Intense warming alcohol presence. Notes of banana, molasses and dried fruit. Rich, thick palate. Soft carbonation is barely noticeable because of the alcohol burn. A delicious, high-octane brew.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2006 An intensely aromatic chocolate cough syrup bath to hunt down all melancholy...Bananas sprinkled with cloves have healing powers too...Berry bubblegum candles emit a languid candied smoke as well as a sweet alcohol flame to appease all perplexing thoughts...This port winish nouveau Trois-Pistoles is a miraculous achievement in escapism...

A best-before-2005 bottle proved to be as aromatic as a fresher bottle, and as complex in its candied fruitiness and roasty complexity. Alcohol still lashes the back of the palate, but is within acceptable levels for a 12% brew. It could have aged a few years more, even though it was at least 3-4 years old.

Hmmm...where to start.  I believe this is the best wheat beer I've ever tried.  Extremely thick on the tongue.  Mouthfeel is excellent.  It feels like milk.  Wheaty flavor is readily apparent, with a bit of alcohol and a light fruity esteriness.  Very much a dessert drink.  Malty, sweet, and very decadent.
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2003 Small head that dissipates quickly; smooth texture; a bit sweeter than I like; definite alcohol aftertaste; I prefer their Dopplebock
Dark color, fruity and smokey aromas and rather thick. A nice Bock beer if not a bit sweet for the variety.

Ooh, what an aroma. Vinous, alcoholic, smoky, all sorts of interesting things. Very dark brown, with quite a bit of carbination. The alcohol is quite noticable in the taste. A hint of bananas too, I think. A good bit of malt backs it all up. Thick, but not syrupy. I'd certainly drink it again.
Strong rootbeer aroma. Coppery brown color.  VERY VERY malty.  This brew has a level, stable, warming taste.  It's actually comforting to drink.  Well done.
Decent, but not as good as the regular Aventinus.  Overly alcoholic in taste.

This beer seemed familiar as soon as I tasted it.  This beer is obviously what the guys at Unibroue were copying when they created Trois Pistole.  I poured an Aventinus into one glass and a Trois Pistole in a separate glasse (always have some of this on hand).  Side by side the had the same dark ruby-brown appearance, smelled almost identical and tasted virtually the same.  After the Aventinus warmed a bit it started to show its alcohol content in both the nose and on the palate.  Delicious sweet bananna, clove, bubble gum flavors. Medium body, mild carbonation (less carbonation than the Pistol).  I paid around $4 a bottle for this.  A 4 pack of Trois Pistole runs me $7.49 at Kroger. Exceptional beer, but if you can get your hands on the Unibroue brew, save your money.
very dark with a nice small head, somewhat fruity, with a roasted taste, nice on a damp rainy evening!

Bottle 08158 from 2001.
Pours very dark cloudy brown, small head, and minimal lacing.  Aroma is powerful - banana, dark fruits (raisin and plum), maybe some apple in there,too.  Flavor starts with some banana, middle has the other fruits mixed in with alcohol, and ends dry with a strong alcohol feel to it.  Very light carbonation, and a good bit of warming alcohol parade around the mouth.
Great complexity in this beer, with cloves especially and some banana.  Very spicy with the alcohol warming.  Good mouthfeel and pronounced flavors all around.

No. 15298 of 2002: This beer poured a huge off white head that held for awhile then subsided to nothing with no lace. It was a murky dark brown color. It had an aroma of malt, cloves and bannanas. A flavor of malt and caramel with slight elements of the alcohol present. A medium, slightly syrupy body to it. I find this to a more rounded beer than the EKU.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2003 1/20/03:  bottle.  nice medium head with a few swiss cheese holes.  head diminishes quickly with no real lacing.  lots of wheat in both the nose and taste.  i can definitely taste the alcohol.  ever so slight hint of spice.  i was thinking that this beer would be more active than it is.  im not a big fan of wheatie beers, but I think that this beer was well designed.

Dark brown body with a quickly disappearing white head.
Yeasty and malty smells. Some of the esters and alcohol come through too.
Flavor starts malty with a bite in the end from the wheat malt, nice. Alcohol is hidden but not deceptive like some Belgians. Nice warming effect on a winters night. The banana/clove flavors are starting to emerge as the beer warms even more (started at ~60 F).
Some pricks on the tongue from the wheat but I like wheat beers so I knew it was coming. Mildly carbonated.
seemed bubble gummy in flavor and taste.  i was a bit schnokered when i tried it so i'll have to give it a second taste

Let me start off with I can't stand wheat beers, if you do, skip over my rating as Sargent Schultz would say "I know nothing, nothing at all".  This beer seems classic to me.  Very yeasty and fruity and I didn't like it.  My ratings reflect the fact that I think it is the best of a style that is very disagreeable to me.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 I've recently had this on draft at the Buckeye Brewing Company.  This is probably the best beer I've ever had!  The bottled version was very, very good, but the draft version blows the bottle away.  I highly recommend it if you get the chance to try it on tap.  It's all this and a stick of bubble gum too!Deep mohogany hazy beer, nice purpley/red highlights, great head retention and lace on sides of glass.  Aroma is very strong clove, bubble gum, banana, wheat malt, peppery, plummy, and a hint of diacetyl.  Alcohol also appears in aroma as it warms.  Clove and malt flavor also up front with dark fruit and alcohol playing supporting rolls; finishes drier than expected for a very malty beer.  Very well balanced.  Alcohol is very subtle warming and not noticeable in the draft version making this a very dangerously good beer. Higher carbonation lends to lighter than actual body.  Very good beer on a cold winter night, or a hot summer day.  If you are able to have this on tap, I highly recommend it!

tasted this the other day at the schneider brauhaus. the main difference between this and regular aventinus was simply that this was a sipping beer whereas aventinus can be swigged. full roasted peach and apricot didn´t become nasty as with so many beers of this strength. great stuff

Sampled at the Weisses Brauhaus in Munich, but it really did not matter as the bottles they came with clearly were meant to be exported to the US - hardly a single german word on them :-). 
Aroma is estery and contains strawberries and bananas. Very dark, but the glasses themselves were made to resemble ice, so not much more could be seen.
Strong banana flavors well set in a 
fullbodied yet refreshing  beer - actually scary with a beer of this strength.

My Minnesotan compatriot, slikwily, gave this brew a perfect score. I too enjoyed it immensely, but am not as generous. The great thing about this Eisbock is that, although very high in alcohol, it doesnt hit you over the head with alcohol taste. Sweet, roasted malt aroma, with pervading alcohol notes. Fine bubble, off-white to light brown, large head; fully lasting. Dark brown in color. Rich, malty taste, with a bite. Very enjoyable in moderation.

Bottle# 16655 of 2002.  Aroma is very sweet and spicy with obvious notes of banana and clove.  Add to that a fair dose of alcohol.  Flavors are about the same, but with a more hidden amount of alcohol.  Warm and pleasant finish.  A nice beer with a deceiving amount of alcohol.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2003 Bottle #02774 from the 2002 batch nice aroma of fruit and malt nice head that lasts for awhile taste was malty with the same fruity tones that are in the aroma nice warm feeling in the finish from the alcohol.All i got to say is what a beer can"t go wrong trying this one folks

Bottle #9886 from 2002. Brought this back from a Sept trip to Chicago. Huge head and fabulous bouquet- great malty aroma oozing with alcohol.  Great malty flavor and not overly sweet. Well attenuated.  Worth the Aventinus name as its a true classic.

Bottle 03420 from 2002.  Well, let me start this review by saying that I was very anxious to try this beer.  I love the original Aventinus but this just blows it out of the water.  The smell alone is better than almost any other beer I have ever had.  Nice, spicy, yeasty, fruity aroma.  The taste is so many more times as complex as the original Aventinus, with sweet malt and so many tiny bubbles.  Gosh, I love the carbonation in this beer because it makes for such an incredibly light and powerful beer.  The beer finishes very warm and very suitable for the 17 degree weather we are experiencing in PA right now.  This beer is an absolute must try and really does deserve a perfect score because I cannot find a single flaw in any aspect of it.  Well worth the somewhat hefty price for a 12oz. bottle.

Im not sure if I should be comparing this to regular Aventinus or not, so I will try not too, even though I want to say it tastes like Aventinus was put on the stove and reduced to a thicker, stronger substance.  Well, I guess that sums it up, and I guess I will compare it to Aventinus.  The main diff. I see (smell) is that it has lost a lot of its wheaty nose - not as much banana and clove.  The malts are predominant on this one - lots of chocolate and plum.  Second place goes to a sly alcohol taste thats nearly hidden but sharply pokes you every once in awile.  This stuffs pretty good.

Pours a very cloudy dark brown color with a big tan head that rapidly disappears. The aroma is very sweet and fruity, quite similar to many barley wines I have tried. Full bodied with high carbonation, this one starts out sweet and wheaty and finishes sweet with a mild alcohol kick in the finish. The only thing I dont like is the high carbonation. Otherwise this is an excellent beer.
A sweet aroma with a medium brown/amber glow.  A little bit of fruit in the taste.  Too high on the carbonation, but the alcohol is well masked.

Great beer!  The aroma was somewhat spicy, coriander...the aroma misled me into thinking that it would taste somewhat weak, but a kickass, full bodied flavor jumped out.  Lots of flavors camem out in the taste: raisin, alcohol, textured malt, roastedness....well done.

Finally, I get to try an eisbock, thanks to Belgianmaid and Littlemonkey!!  Hazy-amber, low to average head.  Very strong taste, with the vinous alcohol flavor that reminds me of an imperial stout.  The aroma somewhat shields the immense strength of the flavor.  Nice sweet, strong finish.  Excellent!
Pretty pearly head.  Smells nice.  A little sour, but not cranky.  Kinda nutty, in a friendly way, like Benny and Joon.  Cumulatively more appealing with each additional sip.

Smooth, Dry, Warm.  Weiss, Ice, Bock.  Complex and flat matures to a caramel or toffee flavor.  Alcoholly strong yet mellow.  Chimay-eque?  without the carbonation.  truly magnificent, cheers.  oh yea, i guess it is banana,

Impressive, powerful aroma with heavy spices, fruitiness, raisins, yeast and very apparent alcohol.  Slight head atop a murky, dark red-brown color and with little to no lacing.          Flavor is similar to the standard Aventinus, but with a very spicy, alcoholic flavor and a different consistency due to the strength.  Very warming, all the way down. Finishes long and alcoholic.  Wow.  This is seriously good.

Is this the German version of a Black and Tan?  Wheaty 
malt, with and interesting flavor.  Has strong wheat-yeast 
aroma, and taste just like a combination of wheat and bock.
Strong body with a kick of alcohol.  Hazy black appearance.

Chestnut with almost no head.  Floaties at the bottom of the bottle.  Caramel aroma with alcohol backing.  Rich body with definite bock qualities.  Caramel and thick, rich and sweet.  Pleasant alcohol aftertaste.

typical clove/banana combo but with a dark, rich, yeasty kick. strong, but didnt make me pucker as most high alcohol content beers are wont to do. course, i ended up tipping over my glass at some point and spilling half the beer. (thank you 11%?) the other beer is in the fridge for hubby. man, do i wanna go drink it....

Ok, Im a sucker for weizenbocks, and Aventinus has always been a guilty pleasure. When I was able to convince a package store in Connecticut to bring in a case, I only passed a few bottles to fellow Aventinus fanatics before taking over half of the case for myself. A nose that is crossed between bananas foster and a great pain perdu and strong vanilla and fruit flavors. The big malt masked the obvious strong alcohol long enough for me to quaff three of these beauties before reminding myself of the dangers of the beers of the family Schneider.

This has tremendous aroma of berries, cloves and banana soaked in bourbon.  The head lasts through the whole glass, topping a body of deep garnet.  The body carries (partially with the help of an unexpected level of effervescence)the weight of boozy berries, cloves and sweet wheat malt.  Huge on the front, funneling towards a finish of alcoholic stupor.  Maybe a bit too boozy.

deep amber color, head was literally gone in less than a minute. very sweet bubbleyum like aroma..very sweet. flavor was also quite fruity and the alcohol not NEARLY as detectable as EKU 28...leaps and bounds better.

First Rate 12/15/01 Deep cloudy brown color, frothy beige head and sheets of lace. Quite noticeable bubblegum aroma in the nose, but to me its quite pleasant. The top-fermenting wheat beer yeasts deliver a wonderful tone to the nose. Spicey and a some what peppery undertone is also present. Sweet, yes, but not overly so, a great beer, that is a pleasant change of pace. Re-Rate 09/29/02 Clear deep amber to brown color, the head is light chocolate in color, the lace adequate, both dissipate rather quickly. Nose is malt, caramel, slightly Bubble Gummy, front is malt and lightly sweet, the top is light, the finish is somewhat sour, dry, light to moderate carbination. Ranks #403 on my current 1000 beer master list.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2003 2002:Huge cap explosion.Barely transparent ruby liquid.Thick,dense,clingy head. Never dies. Aromas bursting with tropical fruits,yeast,and sweet malts.Palate is perfectly carbonated and thick.Flavors are also very full.Very toffeish mouth feel with a chocolate covered banana,finish. The flavors are ever changing and just keep getting more interesting. The fruity and sweet flavors are both SO pronounced yet both,so balanced. Yeast provides plenty of the bubblegum chewiness I was expecting. I am half way through the bottle and am just craving another bottle. This is delicious,satisfying, and world class. Balanced as can be, and overly,delicious as well!
If you like the regular Aventinus, you might want to try this one!  Similar flavors, but with a noticable alcohol presence.   In NJ not much higher priced than the regular so worth trying.

Head scarily huge, didnt think it was ever going to die down; dark muddy appearance, as others have noted.  Aroma of wheat, pineapple, bananas; pleasant but not as huge as one might expect.  Flavor super-malty, alcohol present right away, caramel flavor prominent, yeast, bananas, but alcohol really is overstrong all the way through and has to limit the points.  Finish smoother and drier than I expected, though.  Good, not great, not a patch on reglar ol Aventinus.
Harsh, industrial cleaner aroma, or paint remover.  Flavor not as good as regular Aventinus.
like the regular Advenitus, but more concentrated - good thing its not in the big bottle

I think this one might be even more potent than that 11% ABV it states here.  It tastes much as you would expect.  Like a stronger (more alcoholic) version of standard Aventinus.  The high ABV makes itself known with a slight warming feeling. I did notice a more chocolatey presence over Aventinus though.  Overall pretty good but not as good as the standard stuff.

Reminds me of Aventinus..Hey, it IS Aventinus...Only different....All cloves and sweet malt. Looks like caramel in the glass. I think its ALL alcohol by the taste! Slight plum? Finishes dry. Very good!

Ummm...wow! The aroma is truly wonderful, with nary a hint of alcohol. Big banana and clove and deep malt sweetness. Same in the taste, except a huge alcohol hit smacks you. This is a real sipper, burns like the dickens. Dry at the end. Good body, I felt. Pretty in the glass.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
#01206, 2002: Dark brown color - strange murky look. Pours with large foamy head - tan in color. Unique nose: tangy yeast, sweet malt, wheat and banana. Even uniquer taste - sweet malt, sour yeast, wheat, touch of whiny malt and banana.

A unique beer that is solid quality and very flavorful. Not your run-of-the-mill beer, but one to boraden your tasting horizons. Check it out. Thanks Phoebe!

This beer kicks ass.  I was drinking a few other beers one night had this one last and boy it snuck up on me I was feeling pretty good.  Even with the high 11%abv it taste great. Kind of  bannana,malt. Recommended
Banana clove smell, candi sugar spicy taste.  It tasted like a high ABV brew, but it didnt feel like 11%.  If you like regular Aventinus, make sure you try its bigger brother.  Thanks VENOM!
excellent beer like a liquor. nice after dinner or dessert beer much more drinkable than a eku 28 dont look for this in germany it is made for export

Murky and brownish with practically no head. Aroma is chocolatey, with notes of banana and cloves and hints of alcohol. Taste is absolutely unique and amazing. Like a banana split in a bottle--strong banana flavor, with chocolate and vanilla notes, and some other fruitiness--I guess theres a cherry on top. Also just a hint of cloves or coriander in there. The alcohol comes through a bit too much perhaps,  but no matter, this is an amazing beer.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2003 Reddish brown and cloudy. Strong alcohol notes throughout with a fruit spice mix. Add the standard wheat beer taste and it makes it even greater. Also notice some sweet/sugary tones as well. High carbonation. I had No. 06997 from 2001. Drink it from a hefe-weizen glass. And don't forget the yeast at the bottom!
Very good thankfully that there is only so much avalabld at any given time this stuff is good but finnishes a little rougher than i had hoped but good all the same

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 This is a strange wheat, an Ice bock, I think the freezing process increases the potency of this style, an Ice beer. Cloudy golden-orange color, huge thick white clingy head, fruity yeasty aroma of alcohol, cloves and bananas. Malty sweet fruity, spicy flavors, has a kind of strong alcohol taste in the start and finish, not bad for its high alcohol content.

Wow.  Thick rich with aroma of cloves and hints of smoke.  If ianything initial impression is of a clovey scottish ale.  The wheat characteristics take over soon,  much more clove than banana, and in this case thats good.  Hints of smoke and a strong earthiness are present as well.  This hides its alcohol quite well and is very drinkable despite the strength.  This is an excellent beer.
Cloudy and rather dark.  Very, very malty.  Strong alcohol kick.  A real butt-kicking brew.  A wheat doppelbock.  To be feared!

2001 Bottle # 04043- Fizzy head that disapated quickly. Alcohol, raisons, and other sweet and wheaty notes in the nose.  Alcohol in the breath, a bit fizzy. Sweet malty taste upfront with the alcohol burning up the middle. Vanilla and spice (with yet more tingy alcohol notes) finish it off. As it warmed, the taste grew more complex. The last few tastes were the best.
Lovely thick mouthfeel, loaded with clove, banana and pineapple, with some bubblegum notes, and nary a hint of that 11% ABV.

The first beer a rated on this site was Aventinus, so I guess its appropriate that the Eisbock is my 50th (thats a benchmark, right?)  Monstrous, foamy, cream colored head.  Body is a bit muddier than the regular.  Aroma is similar, but theres a bit less clove, a touch of alcohol, and sour banana, almost like creamed corn?  Syrupy mouthfeel, a bit more tingly due to the higher ABV.  Malt is subdued, not quite as sweet, with maybe some burnt caramel.  Not quite as good as the standard Aventinus, which is one of my all-time favorites, but the Eisbock definitely holds its own.
This is truly an anomaly amongs other eisbocks.  A voluminous head on a high ETOH beer.  Great weiss flavors with a warming feel.  Perhaps a bit more fizz distracts slightly.

This is interesting - huge Teutonic weiss taste augmented with heavier maltier flavours and sugary Begianlike spiciness.  The thing is a funky muddy brown, and the flavours are muddied too, muddled into mostly sweetness at the end of the glass.  High marks for the strong opening weiss tastes at opening, though.
Very creamy and nice cloudy color. I thought it was intesting and very good.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 Sweet, doughy nose with a touch of prunes, smells a little like blackberry brandy. A nice cloudy brown color.  Tastes like sweet bread. Spicy
like a Xmas beer with a strong wheat component.
Malt a-go-go. Big, round mouth feel with a dry
finish. High alcohol. Challenging and not for
everyone, but I enjoy this stuff a lot.
Very tasty but not the religious experience I hoped.Very full bodied and creamy. The alcohol is not overpowering.

2001 bottle (#7785). Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is dark orange-brown, murky, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (cookies, milk chocolate, caramel), moderately yeasty (dough), with a prominent note of alcohol and further notes of banana, clove, dates, allspice, vanilla, brown sugar, etc. Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, moderately acidic. Full body, creamy texture, fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Much like standard Aventinus, but some things are better and some worse: the mouthfeel is extremely thick and very creamy/chewy (the consistency of buttermilk), but the aroma and finish suffer a bit from the extra alcohol (more in the aroma than the finish, thanks to the thick body and strong and lasting flavor profile), and its sweeter as well.

A decent beer, but doesnt really distinguish itself as something special, despite all the effort that goes into brewing it.  To me, the alcohol is amazingly masked, I was expecting a dryer finish.  Plus for my personal tastes, unless a beer has extreme banana clove flavors, I cant get past the wheat flavors.  For the money though, there are much better choices in the cooler.

Big nose on this one, lots of banana and spice in it.  Nice cloudy, dark color, with a pretty head that stuck around.  Good thick texture, chewy enough to be interesting but still pretty quaffable.  Up front flavor is creamy and fruity, with the malts coming up behind.  Quite a nice brew.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2005 Cap popped off with the loudest pffts.  I thought I was hallucinating when I saw this murky liquid come from the bottle.  The yeast was not yet disturbed, and still, the beer resembled purple mud.  I knew I was in for a real treat.  Berry, bubblegum, clove, tropical fruits, yeast and bananas at first sniff.  ALso an underlying note of fresh pineapple.  Wonderful full mouthfeel without being too residual.  Finishes round and long with hints and textures of banana cream pie.  This beer is new to me and should be in everyone"s fridge; that is if you are a beer geek.  A brewing masterpiece.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Eisweizebock? Weird. Anyway... Chestnut brown and hazy. Banana and cloves in the nose. Extremely estery. Big maltyness, I cant stop myself loving this beer.

Immense candy-sweet malty nose with all the clove, vanilla, and
bubblegum phenols of Aventinus.  Spicy initial flavor, followed by a
continued monstrous malt presence (400-pound gorilla kind of presence). 
Sweet, but also packed with melanoidins, as well as some balance
provided by the clove and vanilla phenols.  Finishes with a predictably
gigantic malty finish, mixed in with a hint of warming alcohol, and a
slight moderation in the sweetness indicating a perfectly calculated
hop presence.  God, this was phenomenal beer.
Cloudy foamy appearance.  Witbier nose (thats what it is!).  Stong intense taste with plenty of hops.  Foams in the mouth.  Not exactly thirst-quenching, either.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 Somewhat muddy dark chestnut with light foam.  The aroma is rich milk chocolate, banana, light spice, trace of acohol.  On the palate, that abv is right up front, with the smooth chocolate maltiness pushed back a bit.  Lots of sweet banana, this time without the spice.  Sweet, rich finish.
Very yeasty, spicy, rootbeer, banana aroma.  Alot in the aroma department, but just doesnt perform in the body.  Very spritzy, spicy and too sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 A deep cloudy brown. Thin but persistent creamy head. Aroma is divine. Swirl the glass as you smell and you get loads of fresh cloves and loads of pineapple Flavor seems tp hold more command of the weisse characteristics then its brother. Less fizzy, still nice and bubbly, carbonation pricks a bit. Medium body that holds all the flavores to perfection.  Very creamy and flavorful. The alcohol comes through in the end a bit, drying and then numbing the tounge beautifully. Truely fantastic! I think i might like this a little better, not as rich making it a bit more drinkable! Truley one of the worlds best. Stunning.
